item.title: Prepare data for QUAIDS estimation
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
We need (1) expenditure budget shares, (2) total expenditure and (3) prices for each consumption good and household.
In the UNHS 05, there are 3 categories of food consumption: Away from how, home produced, purchased.
Away from home consumption is aggregated into one food category.
At which price do we value home produced consumption, at producer or consumer prices? The producer price gives the correct opportunity cost. (It disregards that there potentially is no additional supply or demand at this price but this can only be accounted for if a household production model is included.)
Prices must refer to the same units.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Only producer prices are in line with the budget restriction as using the consumer price would increase total budget available to the household. To use consumer price, we have to assume that the farmer can sell the good at market price and buy other goods for that.

item.title: Estimating quality and measurement error corrected prices for QUAIDS
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Following Alfonzo and Peterson 2006, I estimate quality and quantity corrected unit values. Prices for a homogeneous good are assumed to be identical within a sample cluster (some small region which usually is surveyed during the same time period) and a cluster dummy is included in the estimation equation to remove the measurement error. Household characteristic dummies and total expenditure are included in order to remove the quality bias. In addition, we include a unit dummy since the survey reports consumption in various units which cannot be easily converted to one reference unit. Moreover, we add in a variety dummy which picks up the conversion factor for different variants of a good included (e.g. maize cobs, grain, flour). Since the same unit has a different relationship to kilograms for each variant (a liter of maize cobs has a different conversion or extraction factor to grain than maize flour), we include an interaction term for unit and variant dummies. The unit value estimation equation is:
$latex \ln p_i = \alpha_i + \beta_i \ln y + \sum_{l=1}^L \kappa_{il} z_l + \sum_{c=1}^{C-1}\phi_{ic} D_c + \sum_{s=1}^{S-1} \gamma_{is} U_s + \sum_{m=1}^{M-1} \theta_{im} V_m + \sum_{s=1}^{S-1} \sum_{m=1}^{M-1} \delta_{ism} U_s V_m + \epsilon_i $
where p: unit value (=value / quantity), y: total household expenditure, z_l: vector of household characteristics, D: cluster dummy, U: unit dummy, V: variety dummy.
But due to strong heterogeneity of non-food expenditures, quantities are unreliable if given. Thus, non-food expenditures have to be included differently into the demand system.
The vector of household characteristics, in particular, includes log of household size and the demographic composition of the household in terms of shares (as in Deation 1997: 288), i.e. number of kids below 5 as share in total household size, number of kids below 15, below 18, above 60, and the share of males.
References: Deaton 1997, Alfonzo & Peterson 2006, Capeau & Dercon 2006

item.title: Estimation of unbiased unit values
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Data: Uganda National Household Survey 2002/03. Estimation is done on per food aggregate basis (25 aggregates) over the observations which have non-missing values for market price and total value of purchases.  The majority of the 973 cluster dummies turns out significant. By contrast, the demographic composition of household variables, i.e. household size, share of different age and gender groups, come out insignificant. Total expenditure determines price through quality shown by a significant coefficient. Prediction of unbiased price for each household and expenditure aggregate: To get a measurement error and quality bias-corrected unit value, the coefficients for the household characteristics and total expenditure are removed from the prediction equation. Furthermore, unit of quantity and code of variety are removed, because only the price for a base unit and variety is needed for the later estimation of the demand system. $latex \ln p_{ic} = \alpha_i + \phi_{ic} D_{ic} $ Problems:
  1. How to handle (prices of) clusters with no observations for some aggregate good? I replaced those missing prices using the average cluster dummy coefficient of the clusters in the district. If those are also missing, I took the average of those from the region.
  2. About half of the cluster dummy coefficients are non-significant.
  3. The estimated prices are very small compared to the given market prices for the base unit. This improves strongly if the "ln(total expenditure)" term is taken out from the regression. But does the magnitude of this fictitious price actually matter for the QUAIDS estimation?

item.title: QUAIDS model specification
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The equations for the Quadratic Almost Ideal Demand System are given by Banks et al. as follows:
$latex w_i = a_i + \sum_{j=1}^n \gamma_{ij} \ln p_j + \beta_i \ln \left[ \frac{m}{a(p)}\right]+ \frac{\lambda_i}{b(p)}\left \{ \ln \left[ \frac{m}{a(p)}\right ] \right \}^2 $
where price index a(p) :
$latex \ln a(p)=\alpha_0+\sum_{i=1}^K \alpha_i \ln p_i + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^K \sum_{j=1}^K \gamma_{ij} \ln p_i \ln p_j $
and b(p):
$latex b(p)=\prod_{i=1}^{K}p_i^{\beta_i} $
m: total budget, p: price.
Additionally, restrictions based on the theoretical properties are imposed:
Additivity of budget shares ($latex \sum_i w_i=1 $): $latex \sum_{i=1}^K \alpha_i = 1 $, $latex \sum_{i=1}^K \beta_i = 0 $, $latex \sum_{i=1}^K \lambda_i = 0 $ and $latex \sum_{i=1}^K \gamma_{ij} = 0 \hspace{.3cm} \forall j$, (not sure about the gamma. it's a little bit strange in all papers)
Demand functions are homogeneous of degree zero in (p,m): $latex \sum_{j=1}^K \gamma_{ij} = 0 \hspace{.3cm} \forall i $
Slutsky symmetry: $latex \gamma_{ij} = \gamma_{ji} \hspace{.3cm} \forall i \neq j $
i,j=1..K: food groups

item.title: QUAIDS estimation
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
An estimation procedure based on STATA is exemplified in Poi 2002, 2008. The procedure requires budget shares in total expenditures per expenditure item plus prices and total expenditures, for every household.
One conceptual issue is, how to treat consumption from in-kind transfers and home-consumption? Ignoring the origin of the consumed items and assuming that every item can be transformed into other items at market prices, such consumption should also be valued at market prices.
This assumption can be criticized as in-kind transfers and consumption out of own production would only realize farm-gate prices. But valuing those at farm-gate prices, would result in a downwards bias of the estimated consumption. For instance, consumption of 100 kg staples at a market price of 2 $/kg results in a budget share of 50% for staples for a urban household without home production of staples (200/(200+200 for other consumption) but for a rural household with own production of 100 kg staples and this production valued at a farm-gate price of 1 $/kg, the budget share would amount to only 100/(100+200)=1/3. Thus, neither of the two alternative treatments is completely satisfying.
It is common to assume a value $latex \alpha_0$ as this cannot be estimated. This is set to K*1 (see Poi 2002: 404). Deaton & Mulbauer (1980, p. 316) suggest alpha 0 can be seen as a minimum standard of living and thus should be set to log(min(expenditure)) of the household data (see also Banks, Blundell & Lewbel, 1997: 534, footnote 8).
The convergence of the iterative SUR procedure depends strongly on the chosen alpha zero value if the QUAIDS instead of AIDS is used. If following the Deaton suggestion, it converges very slowly. If using alpha0=N, convergence is ok. If alpha0=0, it does not converge at all.

item.title: Revisited: estimation of unbiased unit values
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Excitedly I was packing too much into previous equation which estimates the unbiased unit value. In particular, a common unit conversion factor for very different items is unreasonable. Thus, conversion of VERY close varieties of a good (flour and grain, e.g., where an extraction rate can be justified) and conversion to a base unit should be done in a separate step preceding the actual aggregation and unit value estimation of the aggregate items. Especially for higher levels of aggregation, this might be important.
Furthermore, the large number of clusters with non-significant coefficients is concerning. Hopefully this improves with the above modification of the procedure.

item.title: Handling non-food consumption in the demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The handling of non-food items poses a different challenge than that of food items in that heterogeneity between items is much greater and often quantities are not given, for this very reason. Thus, prices for non-food items cannot be estimated the same way from unit values. I found 2 different approaches in the literature to circumvent this problem and to complete the demand system:
  1. Two-stage budgeting: On the first stage, use a Working-Leser model to allocate the budget to the two categories food and non-food. Then use the QUAIDS only for food demand. In its basic form, the Working-Leser model uses only budget shares and the log of expenditures, i.e., in particular, no prices.  See Ecker 2009.
  2. Include non-food in the QUAIDS system and approximate price for non-food with help of price indices for non-food consumption from the statistics office. See Robles 2009.

item.title: Constructing household-specific non-food price indices
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: We construct household-specific non-food price indices to include non-food consumption directly into the QUAIDS following Robles (2009). Regional consumption price indices for 6 cities and 7 consumption aggregates, fiscal year 2002/03  are taken from the Statistical Abstracts 2007 (UBoS). Problem? The price indices do actually not reflect how prices of the goods relate to each other or how prices of one region relates to those of other regions but only how they changed in relation to the base period (1997/98) and one can see how the change of one good relates to changes of the other good or to changes in other regions. Do these price indices actually contain the information required for the demand system? Discard this approach. But the last table of the CPI data from UBoS actually contains regional prices for many different goods. Together with the actual price indices, I could recover a "level price number" for 2002/2003 for the regions and groups which I can use. use menezes 08 approach? Since then I also only get data points for 6 regions, the added value of doing this might not justify the work. Thus, I stick with Olivier Ecker's approach of estimating a single equation for food demand a la Working-Leser.

item.title: Working-Leser food demand estimation
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
I use the same approach as in Ecker (2009), who augmented the Working-Leser model by a quadratic term.
$latex w_F = \alpha_F + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M + \lambda_F(\ln M)^2 $
where p_f: average food price, M: total household expenditure per capita.

item.title: Incorporating household characteristics into demand systems
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: There are a number of approaches to introduce demographic variables into a demand system (Gorman, demographic scaling, demographic translating).  A household characteristic can change the budget share of an item but must also result in compensating changes of other items shares in order to comply with the budget constraint (if # children increases the budget share of dairy products, it must decrease the shares of other items so that the sum of the budget shares remains 1 => the sum of the so-called "demand shifters" must be zero) (see Sadoulet 1995, ch. 2.5.5 and FAO). Applying demographic translating (Pollak & Wales, 1981), the Working-Leser formula becomes: $latex w_F = \alpha_F' + \sum_{k=1}^{K} \delta_k \eta_k + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M + \lambda_F(\ln M)^2 $ where $latex \alpha_F' = \alpha - \sum_{k=1}^{K} \delta_k \eta_k $ and $latex p_f $: average food price, M total per capita household expenditure. [Alston et al., 2001 modify the formula so that it is invariant against the unit of measurement again] Applying demographic translating to the QUAIDS: $latex w_i = \alpha' + \sum_{k=1}^{K} \delta_{ik} \eta_{k} + \sum_{j=1}^n \gamma_{ij} \ln p_j + \beta_i \ln \left[ \frac{m}{a(p)}\right]+ \frac{\lambda_i}{b(p)}\left \{ \ln \left[ \frac{m}{a(p)}\right ] \right \}^2 $ including the additional adding-up constraint: $latex \sum_{i=1}^n \delta_{ik} = 0 $ The sum over all consumption items of the demand shifters for a particular household characteristic (e.g., # children) must be zero. ??? Why do not any papers using the demographic translating approach in the QUAIDS also include the adding-up constraint ??? formulas, also elasticities, for QUAIDS incorporating demographic translation: heterogeneous preferences in household food consumption in Italy (moro00).pdf

item.title: Aggregate price index for consumption item group
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: The common approach for aggregating the prices for consumption items to a price index for an aggregate item / group seems to be the use of the logarithmic form of a weighted geometric mean (=Stone price index): $latex \ln p_{sc} = \sum_{i \in I_s} \bar{w}^{dc}_{i} \ln p_{ic} $ with $latex I_s$: set of items included in aggregate group s, p: price, c: cluster or region, w: budget share of good i in commodity group s (democratic weight). For this price aggregation equation, see, e.g., Menezes et al.,  2008 who differentiate price indices further by income decile. The Stone price index might cause inconsistent results in estimating demand systems but if the prices are normalized to one before computation of the Stone price index, this "corrected Stone price index" remedies the problem (see Asche and Wessells, 1997). Again, ideally every household consumes every item i. The democratic weight computed excludes households which do not consume any item from aggregate group s. Computation of democratic weights $latex \bar{w}^{dc}_{ic}$: $latex \bar{w}^{dc}_{ic} = \frac{\sum_{h \in H_c} \frac{y_{ih}}{\sum_{j \in I_s} y_{jh}}}{\left| H_c \right|} $ with $latex H'_c$: set of all households in cluster c with at least some expenditure on aggregate item s, i.e. $latex H'_c = \{h | h \in H_c \wedge \sum_{k \in I_s} y_{kh}>0\} $, $latex H_c$: set of households in cluster c, $latex I_s$: set of items in aggregate item s, $latex y_{jh}$: budget household h spent on item j. NOTE:Because of possible endogeneity problems when computing w, I decided not to distinguish between clusters and take weight across all clusters.

item.title: Revalue consumption of home produce
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Assuming consumption and production decisions are completely separable and market prices are the true opportunity costs of the consumption out of home production, the quantity of home produce should be revalued at market prices. When estimating the quality and measurement error corrected prices, the variables on the right hand side may not include the budget equivalent of home consumption since this will be revalued later and would induce endogeneity bias. Instead, I assume that quality differences in prices are sufficiently indicated through the budget on purchased food.
When revaluing home consumption at prices consistent with the market prices, I also introduce a quality part into the home consumption budget assuming that the household would produce food items similar to what it buys.
Quantities have to be converted to the reference unit of each particular item during revaluing.
$latex Q' = Q_{uv} \exp^{ \gamma_u + \theta_v + \delta_{uv} }$
$latex P'= P_{uv} \exp^{-(\gamma_u+\theta_v+\delta_{uv})}$
$latex V'=P' Q'$
where P' and Q': price and quantity measured in reference unit and variety, u: unit, v: variety. The coefficients are taken from the "corrected price estimation equation".

item.title: Food consumption items without prices and quantities
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: If for food consumption items there is only purchase value but neither price nor quantity, these observations can be dropped or some neutral assumption has to be made to not bias the estimates of the demand system. In the UNHS 2002/03, the items concerned are "expenditure in restaurants on food", "Other juice", "Other foods". I use the minimum value of all of these expenditures as the unit price and assume there are no quality nor regional differences. The quantities are derived accordingly.

item.title: Deriving income and price elasticities for Working-Leser demand function
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: Given $latex w_F = \alpha_F + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M $ and $latex w_F = \frac{q_F p_F}{M}$ then $latex \frac{q_F p_F}{M} = \alpha_F + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M $. Derivation of income elasticity of demand (without quadratic term): $latex q_i = \frac{M}{p_F} \left(\alpha_F + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M \right) $ $latex \frac{\partial q_F}{\partial M} = \frac{1}{p_F} \left(\alpha_F + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M \right) + \frac{M \beta_F}{p_F M} = \frac{1}{p_F}w_F + \frac{\beta_F}{p_F}$ Multiply by $latex M/q_F$ to get elasticity: $latex \eta_F = \frac{\partial q_F}{\partial M}\frac{M}{q_F}=\frac{M}{p_F q_F}w_F + \frac{\beta_F}{p_F} \frac{M}{q_F}= 1+ \frac{\beta_F}{w_F}$ Similarly, to get own price elasticity of demand: $latex \frac{\partial q_F}{\partial p_F} = -\frac{M}{p_F^2} \left(\alpha_F + \gamma_F \ln p_F + \beta_F \ln M \right) + \frac{M \gamma_F}{p_F p_F} = -\frac{M}{p_F^2}w_F + \frac{M\gamma_F}{p_F^2} $ Multiply by $latex p_F / q_F$ to get elasticity: $latex \varepsilon_F = \frac{\partial q_F}{\partial p_F}\frac{p_F}{q_F}=-\frac{M}{p_F q_F}w_F + \frac{M}{p_F} \frac{\gamma_F}{q_F}= -1+ \frac{\gamma_F}{w_F}$ The elasticities for the Working-Leser function augmented with a quadratic term: Price: $latex \varepsilon_F = -1 + \frac{\gamma_F}{w_F}$ Income: $latex \eta_F = 1 + \frac{\beta_F}{w_F} + \frac{2 \lambda_F \ln M}{w_F}$ These elasticities will remain the same invariably of inclusion of demand shifters / demographic translation. For derivation of elasticities of AIDS demand system, see Sadoulet and de Janvry (1995), Appendix A.5.2. Authors evaluate the elasticities at the sample mean (usual) or median (rare), i.e. using the mean or median budget share for a commodity group in the formula.

item.title: Estimating the Working-Leser demand function
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: Using budget.total as the dependent variable gives me R2 of >.6 but I think it also introduces simultaneity bias due to both sides including budget.total (the total budget spent depends at least partly on how much is spent on food) and thus should be invalid. Usually one would use budget spent on item/income to get the budget shares but income is subject to large measurement errors in household surveys and thus not used. The best specification I found is: lm(budget.shr ~ log(pidx) + log(budget.total) + I(log(budget.total)^2) + log(hhsize) + I((log(hhsize))^2) + male.shr + urban*reg + log(age.head) + male.head + subsistance + log(hhassets) + edu.head + season + phone + tvradio + motorvehicle + bicycle + donkey, data=wlds.data) with adjusted R2 of 0.32. Using yrsschooling.head instead of edu.head or month instead of season did not improve the R2.

item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
QUAIDS elasticities: an analysis of Greek wood and wood product imports - evidence from the linear quadratic aids (arabatzis09).pdf

Linear QUAIDS: an analysis of Greek wood and wood product imports - evidence from the linear quadratic aids (arabatzis09).pdf (based on matsuda 2006)
AIDS: Marshallian (uncompensated) price elasticities: (taken from Green 1990) $latex \varepsilon_{ij} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{1}{w_i} \left[ \gamma_{ij} - \beta_i (\alpha_j + \sum_k \gamma_{kj}\ln{p_k}) \right ]$ with Kronecker delta defined as $latex \delta_{ij} = \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}l} 1 \hfill & {{\rm if }\hspace*{3pt} i=j \hspace*{3pt} {\rm and}} \hfill \\ 0 \hfill & {{\rm otherwise.}} \\ \end{array}} \right. $ For compensated price elasticities use Slutsky equation: (Green 1990) $latex \varepsilon^H_{ij} = \varepsilon_{ij} + \left(\frac{\beta_i}{w_i} + 1 \right )w_j $
Expenditure elasticities for non-linear AIDS: (taken from Pofahl 2005) $latex \eta_i = \frac{\beta_i}{w_i}+1$
For derivation of elasticities see Barnett and Seck (2008).

Marginal budget shares are defined as $$b_i = w_i \eta_i$$

item.title: Censoring in QUAIDS
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
("Censored" in this context means "not selected", see Tauchmann, 2008) Computational capacity limits the an unbiased, fully consistent  and efficient estimation of censored demand systems. Thus, several two-step procedures with reduced computational demands have been introduced, see Tauchmann (2008).  Acknowledging, that the Shonkwiler and Yen (1999) (henceforth SY) two-step procedure has been shown to be inefficient and being outperformed by a Heckman-style estimator (see Tauchmann 2005, 2008), we use the SY procedure as a first approach. Shonkwiler and Yen (1999) estimate the following model: $latex \begin{array}{*{2}l} y^*_{it} = x'_{it} \beta_i + \varepsilon_{it} \\ d^*_{it} = z'_{it} \alpha_i + \upsilon_{it} \\ d_{it} = \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}l} 1 \hfill & {{\rm if }\hspace*{3pt} d^*_{it}>0 \hspace*{3pt} {\rm and}} \hfill \\ 0 \hfill & {{\rm if} \hspace*{3pt} d^*_{it} \leq 0} \\ \end{array}} \right.\\ y_{it}=d_{it} y^*_{it} \\ \end{array}$ where i: commodity, t: observation, x and z: vectors of exogenous variables, $latex y_{it}$ and $latex d_{it}$: observed dependent variables and $latex y^*_{it}$ and $latex d^*_{it}$ there unobserved, latent counterparts. The SY procedure is (see Tauchmann 2005: 368):
  1. Estimate a probit model for each commodity i equation. Then calculate $latex \Phi(z'_{it} \hat{\alpha}_i)$ and $latex \phi(z'_{it} \hat{\alpha}_i)$ where $latex \phi$: univariate standard normal probability density function PDF and $latex \Phi$: cumulative distribution (or density) function CDF.
  2. Estimate the following equation by SUR for the whole sample including censored observations. $latex y_{it}= \Phi(z'_{it} \hat{\alpha}_i) x'_{it}\beta_i + \delta_i \phi(z'_{it} \hat{\alpha}_i) + \xi_{it} $ for all i
An application of a QUAIDS taking into account censoring (Shonkwiler & Yen approach) and appropriately modified formulas for elasticities is Mutuc, Pan, and Rejesus (2007). S&Y in LA/AIDS: Alfonzo and Peterson (2006). Or Jonas and Roosen (2008) with elasticity formulas. The CDF can be obtained in R by using pnorm(predict(probit.res)) and the PDF by dnorm(predict(probit.res)). In context with LA/AIDS Akbay and Boz (2007). A procedure to correct covariance matrices from two-step estimations is given in Murphy and Topel (1985) (which according to Mutuc et al., 2007 has to be applied to Shonkwiler & Yen approach). A critique on the Heien and Wessells (1990) approach and improvement: A note on Heckman-type corrections in models for zero expenditures (Vermeulen 2001) Tauchmann 2005, 2008 compares different zero-expenditure censoring approaches and suggests a new Heckman-type two-step approach which supposedly is consistent.

item.title: Higher disaggregation of commodities in demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Using a higher level of disaggregation, the problem of zero consumption and non-observed unit values gets more severe. In the UNHS02, a disaggregation to 25 food groups includes a couple of clusters showing now purchases for several food groups. This raises a problem in calculating an aggregate unit value for those food groups. The aggregate unit value ("price") is designed to account for expenditure composition differences of households and thus the individual prices are weighted with their expenditure shares. Options:
  1. Use an average of the prices for a larger region.
Idea: Does a price which reflects individual budget shares on underlying commodities actually induce simultaneity bias? Households with higher income might consume a higher value composition of goods which should be rather captured by the income variable. Thus: Use democratic budget shares  over the survey as weights.

item.title: Hicksian / compensated price elasticities of demand
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The compensated price elasticities can be calculated using the uncompensated (Marshallian) price elasticities and the income or expenditure elasticities of demand on basis of the Slutsky equation. $latex \varepsilon_F^H = \varepsilon_F + \eta_F w_F $
The compensated price elasticities say by how many percent the demand for good i increases if the price for good j increases by 1%, assuming that the household is compensated so that it can stay on the same utility level. This shows the pure substitution effect, leaving the income effect out.

item.title: Unconditional elasticities in a two-stage demand system
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Based on "Unconditional Elasticities in Two-Stage Demand Systems: An Approximate Solution" by Carpentier & Guyomard (2001). Summarized on page 226, (20a,b,c).
Unconditional expenditure elasticity:
$latex \eta^{\bar{c}}_i = \eta_{i|g}\eta_g $
Unconditional Hicksian price elasticity:
$latex \varepsilon^{H,\bar{c}}_{ij} = \varepsilon^{H}_{ij} + w_{j|h} \varepsilon^H_{gh}\eta_{i|g}\eta_{j|h}$
Unconditional Marshallian price elasticities:
$latex \varepsilon^{\bar{c}}_{ij} = \varepsilon_{ij} + w_{j|h} \left( \frac{\delta_{gh}}{\eta_{j|h}} + \varepsilon_{gh}\right) \times \eta_{i|g}\eta_{j|h} + w_{h}w_{j|h}\eta_g\eta_{i|g} \times (\eta_{j|h}-1)$
where g, h: food groups of first stage, $latex ^{\bar{c}}$: indicates unconditional elasticities, $latex w_{i|g}$: share of good i in budget of group g, $latex \eta_{i|g}$: conditional elasticity of good i in group g. $latex \varepsilon^{H}_{ij} \text{ and } \varepsilon_{ij}= 0 \text{ if } i \in I_h, j \in I_g \text{ and } g \neq h$ because of the weak separability assumption between item groups, and $latex \delta_{gh}$ Kronecker delta, =1 if g=h and =0 otherwise.
These elasticities are valid only when the theoretical properties of demand functions are satisfied, i.e., homogeneity, adding-up, symmetry.

item.title: Zero quantity demand issue
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The issue of censoring or zero demands in observed household expenditures is rather severe in a 10 group aggregation of food items, separately for urban and rural areas. The range is between 0 and 61.5% where fish and matooke have the highest percentages of censored values. Only 283 of the 7421 households have consumed all of the 10 items during the surveyed period. What options do exist to cope with this issue?
  1. Higher / different aggregation: aggregate food items so that within % of censored values undercuts 10%. Problems: Such aggregation might not exist. Important food items might get disguised in an aggregate. Responsiveness of demand necessarily decreases with stronger heterogeneity within food groups.
  2. Limited dependent variable approaches: Shonkwiler & Yen, Tauchmann / Heckman. Problems: Difficult to implement: Solution algorithm has to be redone. Different formulas for elasticities. Theoretical assumptions like adding up of shares cannot be enforced.
2. seems by far superior. But how can it be implemented?
  1. Estimate an AIDS/LA by SUR. This is probably the easiest way. All formulas have to be adapted but most can probably be found in the literature and derivation is not that difficult. The properties of AIDS/LA have no good reputation.
  2. Estimate AIDS: Need to adapt the Blundell estimator used in micEconAids. Complex.
With both methods I probably have to estimate the full system of n equations and cannot enforce the theoretic constraints.

item.title: Bootstrap elasticity standard errors and significance
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The standard errors for the regression coefficients of multiple stage demand systems and censored two-step demand systems as in my model are very difficult to derive analytically. For the censored two-step demand systems there is actually an analytical correction method by Murphy-Topel, also explained in the Greene book. However, the easier method is the non-parametric bootstrap.
The bootstrap is based on drawing R artificial samples of size N each from the original sample (which has N observations) with replacement. Then, the statistic to approximate is computed for each of the R samples.
In the case of elasticities, we perform the regressions on each of the R samples drawn and compute the elasticities. The standard errors for the coefficients are calculated with the usual sample standard deviation formula (squared deviations from the mean divided by R-1). Confidence intervals can be constructed in several ways (see John Fox's chapter "Bootstrapping Regression Models"). The bootstrap percentile interval is simply constructed by taking the two elasticity estimates of the R estimates so that, e.g., exactly 2.5% of the estimates are below resp. above the respective estimate. But this confidence interval is supposed to perform poorly and the so called bias-corrected, accelerated percentile interval ($$ BC_{\\} $$) is preferred.
The bias of the statistic is defined as the difference between the originally computed statistic and the mean of that statistic over the bootstrap sample. I.e., statistic-bias = mean(bootstrap observations of statistic).

item.title: Derive censored QUAIDS elasticities
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Censored QUAIDS formulas (Shonkwiler & Yen): $latex w_i = \Phi_i \alpha_i + \Phi_i \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k + \Phi_i \beta_i \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) + \frac{\Phi_i \lambda_i}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 + \phi_i$ with $latex \ln a(p) = \alpha_0 + \sum_{k \in I} \alpha_k \ln p_k + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k \in I} \sum_{l \in I} \gamma_{kl} \ln p_k \ln p_l $
$latex b(p) = \prod_{k \in I} p_k^{\beta_k} $
$latex w_i = \frac{q_i p_i}{m} $
$latex \frac{\partial \ln a(p)}{\partial p_j} = \frac{\alpha_j}{p_j} + \frac{1}{p_j} \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k $ (depends on symmetry of gamma!)
$latex \frac{\partial b(p)}{\partial p_j} = \beta_j p_j^{-1} \prod_{k \in I} p_k^{\beta_k} = \frac{\beta_j}{p_j} b(p) $
$latex q_i = \frac{m}{p_i} \left[ \Phi_i \alpha_i + \Phi_i \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k + \Phi_i \beta_i \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) + \frac{\Phi_i \lambda_i}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 + \phi_i \right] $
Derive expenditure elasticity: $latex \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial m} = \frac{1}{p_i} w_i + \frac{m}{p_i} \left[ \frac{\Phi_i \beta_i}{m} + \frac{2 \Phi_i \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \frac{1}{m} \right] $
$latex \boxed{\eta_i = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial m} \frac{m}{q_i} = 1 + \frac{\Phi_i}{w_i} \left[ \beta_i + \frac{2 \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right]} $
Own-price elasticity (uncompensated):
$latex \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial p_i} = -\frac{m}{p_i^2} w_i + \frac{m}{p_i} \left[ \Phi_i \gamma_{ii} \frac{1}{p_i} - \Phi_i \beta_i \left( \frac{\alpha_i}{p_i} + \frac{1}{p_i} \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k \right) + \frac{2 \Phi_i \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \left( - \frac{\alpha_i}{p_i} - \frac{1}{p_i} \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k \right) - \Phi_i \lambda_i \frac{\beta_i}{p_i b(p)} \left( \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right] $
$latex \varepsilon_{ii} = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial p_i} \frac{p_i}{q_i} = -1 + \frac{\Phi_i}{w_i} \left[ \gamma_{ii} - \left( \beta_i + \frac{2 \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right) \left( \alpha_i + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k \right) - \frac{\lambda_i \beta_i}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left(\frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right] $
Cross-price elasticity (uncompensated):
$latex \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial p_j} = \frac{m}{p_i} \left[ \Phi_i \gamma_{ij} \frac{1}{p_j} - \Phi_i \beta_i \left( \frac{\alpha_j}{p_j} + \frac{1}{p_j} \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \right) - \Phi_i \lambda_i b(p)^{-2} \frac{\beta_j}{p_j} b(p) \left( \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 - \frac{2 \Phi_i \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \left( \frac{\alpha_j}{p_j} + \frac{1}{p_j} \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \right) \right] $
$latex \varepsilon_{ij} = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial p_j} \frac{p_j}{q_i} = \frac{\Phi_i}{w_i} \left[ \gamma_{ij} - \left( \beta_i + \frac{2 \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right) \left( \alpha_j + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \right) - \frac{\lambda_i \beta_j}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left(\frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right] $
General price elasticity:
$latex \boxed{\varepsilon_{ij} = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial p_j} \frac{p_j}{q_i} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{\Phi_i}{w_i} \left[ \gamma_{ij} - \left( \beta_i + \frac{2 \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right) \left( \alpha_j + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \right) - \frac{\lambda_i \beta_j}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left(\frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right]} $
with
delta: Kronecker Delta =1 if i=j and =0 otherwise.

item.title: Complete AIDS model formulation
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
$latex w_i = \alpha'_i + \sum_{k \in K} \delta_{ik} z_k + \sum_{j \in I}^n \gamma_{ij} \ln p_j + \beta_i \ln \left[ \frac{m}{a(p)}\right] $
where:
$latex \ln a(p)=\alpha_0+\sum_{i \in K} \alpha_i \ln p_i + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{i \in I} \sum_{j \in I} \gamma_{ij} \ln p_i \ln p_j $ and I is the set of food groups.
Additionally, the demand system should satisfy the following constraints in order to comply with demand system theory, namely \noindent additivity of budget shares so that $latex \sum_{i \in K} w_i=1 $: $latex \sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i = 1 ,\; \sum_{i \in I} \beta_i = 0,\; \sum_{i \in I} \gamma_{ij} = 0 \hspace{.5cm} \forall j \in I $
homogeneity of degree zero in $latex p $: $latex \sum_{j \in I} \gamma_{ij} = 0 \; \forall i \in I, $
and Slutsky symmetry: $latex \gamma_{ij} = \gamma_{ji} \; \forall i,j \in I. $
To implement the demographic translation approach, one additional constraint is required which guarantees that the effect of each demand shifter cancels out when added up across all items: $latex \sum_{i \in I} \delta_{ik} = 0 \hspace*{.5cm} \forall k \in K $
The elasticity formulas for the non-linear AIDS are given \citep[see][]{green90} as follows.
Expenditure elasticities: $latex \eta_i = \frac{\beta_i}{w_i}+1 $
Uncompensated price elasticities: $latex \varepsilon_{ij} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{1}{w_i} \left[ \gamma_{ij} - \beta_i \left(\alpha_j + \sum_k \gamma_{kj}\ln{p_k}\right) \right ] $ with Kronecker delta defined as $latex \delta_{ij} = \left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}l} 1 \hfill & {{\rm if }\: i=j \: {\rm and}} \hfill \\ 0 \hfill & {{\rm otherwise.}}\\ \end{array}} \right. $
For interpretation of the model parameters, see Edgerton (1996: 64).

item.title: Interpreting demand elasticities
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Income elasticity of demand (Yed):
  • Yed>0: normal good
    • Yed<1: necessity good
    • Yed>1: luxury / superior good
  • Yed<0: inferior good
Price elasticity of demand (Ped):
  • 0<|Ped|<1: price inelastic
  • |Ped|=1: price unit elastic
  • |Ped|>1: price elastic
  • Giffen good: demand increases when its price rises (Ped>0)
Cross-price elasticity of demand (CPed):
  • CPed>0: complements
  • CPed=0: independent
  • CPed<0: substitutes

item.title: Rank of a demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: "The rank of a demand system is the dimension of the space spanned by its Engel curves. In particular, if the Engel curves for all commodities are linear in the log total expenditure, then the rank is two. On the other hand, if the rank exceeds two, then a nonlinear term such as a quadratic term should be added to approximate the Engel curve." (Unayama, 2006) "Lewbel (1990) definiert den Rang eines Nachfragesystems als die ma- ximale  Dimension  des  durch  die  Engel-Kurven des  Nachfragesystems aufgespannten Raumes. item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Werf, 2009:
GTAP: for landowners, different uses of their lands are imperfect substitutes. Restriction is not on amount of land but on value of land.
GTAP-AEZ: land quality differentiated into 18 AEZs (6 lengths of growing period X 3 climate zones). Land within an AEZ are of similar soil type, landform, and climatic characteristics. Land is mobile between crop, livestock, and forestry but not across AEZs. Only substitution of land of the same AEZ. "Sufficiently high" elasticity of substitution assures that return on land across AEZs, but within a given use, will move closely together. Land supply within an AEZ is constrained by a CET. item.title: Modelling land allocation for Uganda EPA paper
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
We want to introduce a nesting structure  into the land supply so that land has different substitutability between different crops. Therefore, land will be aggregated by a CET structure across several levels. The top level consists of all crop land, the level below distinguishes crop land with lower substitutability and then the last level aggregates crops with high substitutability. For all these levels and lands new land factor accounts are needed in the SAM. Each activity pays to a specific type of land, e.g. maize land, and each specific land pays to the different household types. Therefore, we need to compute the distribution of these land types across households. The CET approach of land supply is described by Palatnik (2009) as follows:
Conceivably  the  simplest  method  of  introducing  endogenous  land-use  allocation  in  a  CGE model is constraining industrial land stock through a Constant Elasticity of Transformation (CET) function, by which an aggregate endowment of land is transformed across alternative uses, subject to  some  transformation  parameters,  determining  the  responsiveness  of  land  supply  to  changes  in relative  yields.  Land  owners  rent  out  land  to  uses  that  give  the  highest  return,  under  the  CET constraint. Perfect competition on input and output markets assures that all markets, including that of land, clear.

item.title: CET-nested land supply
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
There is only one factor land LND which can be demanded and used in production functions.
LND is a composite of lands used by different activities/sectors L1 to Ln. (Q_LND = CET(Q_L1,Q_L2,...,Q_Ln))
There is a separate land rent for each land used by each sector reflecting the productivity of the land for the particular sector.
This type of land supply has been suggested, e.g., in Hertel and Tsigas (1988), see formulation in Keeney and Hertel (2009).
A land owner has a fixed area of land and rents it out to different activities / sectors to maximize his returns from land subject to limitations to the transformation of land from one use to another which is formulated as a constant elasticity of transformation (CET) function.
$latex \max \sum_{s \in S} W_s X_s $
s.t. $latex A = \left( \sum_s \theta_s X_s^\rho \right)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} $
where A: fixed amount of land, $latex X_s $: land allocated to sector s, $latex W_s $: return from land allocated to sector s, $latex \theta_s $: share parameter, $latex \rho = 1-\frac{1}{v}$ with $latex v $ elasticity of transformation.
In fact, not the land quantity but the rental share weighted quantity of land is kept constant which implies that $latex \sum_s \theta_s \frac{\Delta X_s}{X_s} = 0 $ (see Keeney and Hertel, 2009, footnote 5).

item.title: Implementing sluggish factor supply (for land)
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: The first attempt is to imitate the approach in GTAP where land is implemented as a sluggish factor meaning that land supply to different activities is restricted through a CET land supply function. (For differences and formulas regarding CES and CET functions see an der Mensbrugghe (2005), Annex C) To model this, the factor price distortion variable WFDIST is made variable while WF is fixed. The only real equation to be added is the first-order optimality condition of the land supply optimization problem of the land owner (see derivation of the formulas: CET land supply calibration, very helpful: Sancho (2009) and van der Mensbrugghe (2005), Annex C). $latex QF_{fa} = QFSPU_f * \left( \sum_{i} \frac{(WF_f * WFDIST_{fi})^{\frac{\rho_f}{\rho_f-1}}}{\delta_{fi}^{\frac{1}{\rho_f-1}}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\rho_f}}\frac{(WF_f * WFDIST_{fa})^{\frac{1}{\rho_f-1}}}{\delta_{fa}^{\frac{1}{\rho_f-1}}} $ The CET land supply function returns an aggregate of "productive units" $latex QFSPU_f $ which is not equal to the sum of land quantities put in thus not equal to the real fixed land supply QFS. Hence, we add another equation which introduces a conversion multiplier $latex FSPUCONV_f $ that converts the "productive units" aggregate of the CET to match the QFS quantity. $latex QFSPU_f = FSPUCONV_f*QFS_f $ $latex \rho_f = \frac{\sigma + 1}{\sigma} $: CET parameter, $latex \sigma = \frac{1}{\rho_f -1} $: elasticity of transformation. With $latex \sigma $ externally given, $latex \delta $ can be calibrated: $latex \delta_{fa} = QFS0_f^{\rho_f - 1} * \frac{WFA_{fa}}{QF0_{fa}^{\rho_f-1}} $ where $latex QFS0_f, WFA_{fa}, QF0_{fa} $ are the initial quantity of factor supply, the initial factor wage in sector a, and the initial quantity of factor demand in sector a computed from the SAM. Since the sluggish factor supply actually need extra equations, this has to be set up in the uganda.dat file rather than in the simulations file. During the generation of the model it is necessary to know to which factors this applies to. The sim.gms file has been modified to automatically recognize that the sluggish factor closure has been applied for the particular factor. The factor market balance also applies to sluggish factors so that supply of quantity of land is equal to demand of quantity of land: $latex \sum_{a \in A} QF_{fa} = \overline{QFS}_f $

item.title: A problem with the 2005 Uganda SAM (IFPRI)
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The experiments with nested land supply modeling for the IFPRI standard model revealed that there is some problem with the domestic fuel sector afuel / cfuel which uses very small shares / quantities of the factor unskilled labor.  This resulted in the model being unsolvable under across-the-board import tax cut scenarios. Setting the production elasticity (elasticity of substitution between factors in the CES production function) to 0.01 resolved the problem but now factor substitution is basically non-existent for the fuel sector. As it turns out, this did fix it for a full liberalization scenario but not for more complex tariff cut scenarios like the EPA one. Now, I have
  • aggregated lab-self with lab-unsk to get rid of very small lab-unsk values in some agricultural sectors
  • introduced only marketing margins TRNCST for DOM and IMP since from the SAM it looks like such payments don't occur for exports and there were solution problems exactly for all sectors with imports.
  • set the prodelas for fuel to the original value again.
NLP solver doesn't solve but PATH gives an optimal solution although it reports 2 errors. Anyway, for now I go with this solution. 28-07-2010 As it turns out, this was not the end of the problem. Eventually, it seems that everything is working after the following changes:
  • aggregate achem+afert+afuel: afert and afuel were tiny sectors with tiny factor use.
  • aggregate the marketing margins / transaction costs (trc) into aosrv: the sam has only one account for transaction costs. It is too big to be only for domestic commodities and it is unclear how to spread that over domestic, import, export. I did it according to values but this seems to make the model very fragile.
  • aggregate ardev into aosrv and crdev into cosrv: rdev is tiny.
  • change the land transformation elasticity from -0.25 to -0.3 for within perennial crops and between perennials and annuals, the elasticity for within annual crops is -1.1. Solvability of the model seems to critically depend on the elasticities chosen for this. I hope this is not a problem of my model formulation. (Note, the other changes were also necessary when I used a model without land CETs.)
  • (the prod elasticity for fuel is back to initial level and lab-self is separate from lab-unskll)
After this the 2009, EPA, and free trade scenarios worked with land being sluggish in the 2-level nesting. (solver ends with optimal solution but the report summary indicates there were 1 to 4 errors during the solution process. But this was only during the process and the solution is valid and optimal.)

item.title: Implement nested CET function for land supply in GAMS
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Building on the functions derived in the post on implementing sluggish factor supply, we now add a nesting structure so that different sets of activities can have different elasticities of factor substitution. The idea is to add friction to moving land from and between perennial crops to annual crops as this is a strong management decision. Perennials require several years till the yield a full harvest. Moreover, land likely has been put to the use it is most suited for so that switching crops could also result in less productivity. We assume that annual crops are more easily substitutable than perennials.
Land supply is derived from the rent return maximization problem of the land owner. The land owner will rent out for different uses according to the rent returns, as explained in the previous post. Now, there is first a decision on whether to rent to annual crops or perennials (level 0 CET function) and then it is decided on the particular crop within those groups (level 1 CET function, one for each crop group).
The level one CET optimality condition (substitution between crops within one branch of the nest): $latex QF_{fa} = QFSPUL1_{fs} * \left( \sum_{b \in A_s} \frac{(WF_f*WFDIST_{fb})^{\frac{\rho^{L1}_{fs}}{\rho^{L1}_{fs}-1}}}{{\delta^{L1}_{fb}}^{\frac{1}{\rho^{L1}_{fs}-1}}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\rho^{L1}_{fs}}}\frac{(WF_f*WFDIST_{fb})^{\frac{1}{\rho^{L1}_{fs}-1}}}{{\delta^{L1}_{fa}}^{\frac{1}{\rho^{L1}_{fs}-1}}} $
To tie the CET function value ("productive units") to the physical quantity, a conversion factor is introduced: $latex QFSPUL1_{fs} = FSPUCONVL1_{fs}*\sum_{a \in A_s} QF_{fa} $
The level 1 CET also needs a price for the CET aggregate from level 0: $latex WFSFL1_{fs} = \frac{QFSPUL1_{fs}}{\sum_{a \in A_s} WF_f*WFDIST_{fa}*QF_{fa}} \; \forall s \in S, f \in F_s $
On level 0 the CET aggregates the CET aggregates from level 1: $latex QFSPUL1_{fs} = QFSPUL0_f * \left( \sum_{t \in S} \frac{WFSFL1_{ft}^{\frac{\rho^{L0}_f}{\rho^{L0}_f-1}}}{{\delta^{L0}_{ft}}^{\frac{1}{\rho^{L0}_f-1}}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\rho^{L0}_f}}\frac{WFSFL1_{fs}^{\frac{1}{\rho^{L0}_f-1}}}{{\delta^{L0}_{fs}}^{\frac{1}{\rho^{L0}_f-1}}} $
And finally, the level 0 CET function value is tied to those of level 1: $latex QFSPUL0_{f} = FSPUCONVL0_{f}*\sum_{s \in S} QFSPIL1_{fs} $
S is the set of names of activity sets, i.e., S={annuals, perennials}, in our case.

item.title: Constructing EPA tariff schedule to SAM mapping
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
We need a mapping of the HS codes to the SAM sectors in order to apply the EPA tariff structure. Moreover, as the base scenario, an economy with an implemented EAC CET is desired.
The HS to SAM concordance starts from the HS Combined to GTAP concordance has provided by WITS. The GTAP sectors are mapped to the SAM sectors and, where necessary, have to be modified by hand. The modifications in particular are required for the GTAP sectors GRO, V_F, PFB, OCR, CTL, OAP, OFD as the Uganda SAM is more detailed in the agricultural sectors. Moreover, meat, fish and grain processing need to be separated and fuel, fertilizer, and furniture sectors do not exist in GTAP.
The HS search web page http://www.foreign-trade.com/reference/hscode.htm was very handy for this.
All the HS codes of the Ugandan import from the world for 2005 data from TRAINS are completely included in the constructed concordance. Of the EAC EPA schedule one HS 6 line is missing, 560190, but this also does not exist in the official HS definition. In general, the EAC EPA schedule reports imports for more HS 6 lines as is apparent from the TRAINS import data. There are from year to year variations but the number of additional lines with reported imports in the EPA document is about 300.
We use 2005 trade volumes to construct the aggregate tariff scenarios for the baseline and EPA scenarios in order to stay consistent with the 2005 SAM. Tariff data is take from TRAINS for the year 2009.
The EAC EPA schedule is based on HS 8-digit codes so that these have to be aggregated to HS 6 first. We compute the average for each HS 6 line by using the import values from the EPA as weights. In case there is no import occurring on the line, we use the simple average. This actually affects only 3 lines of non-EU and 1 line of EU imports with 175000 and 2000 dollars altogether, respectively.
Two lines with actual imports in 2005 do not appear in the EPA schedule, totaling 170,000 USD. We set these EPA tariffs to zero (had a tariff of 10% in the TRAINS data).

item.title: Construct EPA scenarios
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Since the Uganda SAM is for 2005, the implicit tariffs do not represent the EAC CET tariff and thus are not a good baseline for the EPA simulation. Thus, it is necessary to simulate a current tariff structure to generate a baseline. Here, we use the 2009 tariffs as provided by TRAINS.
The tariffs have to be aggregated to the SAM sectors which is done using import values of 2005 as given by TRAINS/COMTRADE. All scenarios, i.e., the 2005, 2009 baseline, and the EPA are constructed by using the import tariff of the respective year but weighted with the 2005 import value.
One problem is that TRAINS does not return any tariff when there is no trade on a line so that the non-existent tariff is replaced by zero. This introduces inconsistencies as the tariff appears as zero through trade weighting for 2009 but as some higher rate in the EPA. However, the EPA cannot increase existing tariffs. The way forward is to use the raw data for tariffs from TRAINS and extract the effectively applied tariff, i.e. use the respective tariff rate for each country according to their preference region membership. (ask Patrick if he has already a script for that.)

item.title: The negative income from household enterprises problem, again
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Considering revenue and expenditure as well as stock changes for household farm or non-farm enterprises of results in a negative net income from that activity. It is likely that this originates from the short recall periods in conjunction with batch purchases or longer-term investment. But it seems difficult to get any sensible measure of income from such activities as one would rather need to observe the income over a longer time frame, e.g. a year or longer. We can assume that income from each separate household activity is positive in the medium run as the household would give up on this otherwise. In a view from the poverty measurement side, what part of the enterprise activity is relevant from keeping the household from living below the poverty line during that year? Expenditure and revenues are directly effective. But a household close to the poverty line will in general not be able to place larger expenditures from savings. Thus, is this a problem negligible in context with poverty measurement? If such negative incomes to zero when computing the total household income, this should only bias the income source composition of richer households as the "income level" is approximated by the expenditure level.
  • non-farm enterprise income: set all incomes <0 to zero
  • livestock incomes: aggregate all different positions for the household, i.e., livestock stock changes+sales, sales of livestock products, expenditure for livestock, and autoconsumption of livestock,  and hire received from hiring out livestock. If negative, set to zero

item.title: Microsimulation: project CGE results
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
1. Expenditures

UNHS05 household expenditures have been aggregated to commodity accounts, direct tax account, and between household transfers.
  • Consumption out of purchases and away from home (Vpurch): commodity accounts: multiplied by changes in consumer prices (PQX) direct tax (dtax): none yet transfers to households (hhd): none transfers to government (gov): none
  • Consumption out of own produce (Vauto): commodity accounts: multiplied by changes in producer prices (PXX) direct tax (dtax): none transfers to households (hhd): none transfers to government (): none
  • Consumption received as gifts in kind (Vinkind): commodity accounts: multiplied by changes in consumer prices (PQX) direct tax (dtax): none transfers to households (hhd): none transfers to government (): none

2. Income

The income consists of all revenue minus costs, including costs of factors, intermediate inputs, and household enterprise activities. It comprises revenues from activity accounts, inputs in form of factors labor and land (capital and cattle currently not included) and intermediates. Moreover, it includes "incomes" in form of auto- and free consumption, private transfers and from financial assets.
  • factor returns: multiplied by changes in factor returns (WF)
  • for factors with limited mobility, the entire factor x activity matrix is needed and multiplied by WFDIST
  • for unskilled labor, since the wage is fixed but quantity variable: multiplied by change in quantity supplied QFS. This assumes that all households put proportionally more hours worked in.
  • revenue from activities: by producer prices (PXX)
  • expenditure for intermediates / commodities: consumer price
  • noncrop: none (should this maybe added to forest?)
  • auto.cons:
  • free.cons:
  • private transfers: none
  • returns from financial assets: none
Although income in form of auto and in-kind consumption is likely is not subject to direct income tax, there is no distinction of such incomes of households in the CGE model. For sake of consistency, we apply the income tax to all disposable income also in the microsimulation model.

item.title: Compute non-food expenditure elasticity from Working-Leser regression
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
In the QUAIDS paper I forgot to calculate the non-food elasticities. The missing coefficients can be derived when we assume adding-up: The budget shares must add up to 1 and intercept coefficients as well. All other coefficients must add up to zero. E.g., $latex w_{non-food} = 1-w_{food}$ and $latex \beta_{non-food} = -\beta_{food}$. The expenditure elasticity of non-food is $latex \eta_{\bar{F}} = 1 + \frac{-\beta_F}{1-w_F} + \frac{2(-\lambda_F)\ln M}{1-w_F}$   This expenditure elasticity can also be calculated from the expenditure share and elasticity of food using the adding-up condition: $latex \sum_i p_i q_i = M$ Deriving with respect to M: $latex \sum_i p_i \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial M} = 1$
$latex \sum_i p_i \frac{M q_i}{M q_i} \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial M} = 1$
$latex \sum_i \frac{p_i q_i}{M} \eta_i = 1$
For the specific food vs. non-food case: $latex \frac{q_F p_F}{M} \cdot \eta_F + \frac{q_{NF} p_{NF}}{M} \cdot \eta_{NF} = 1$
$latex \eta_{NF} = \frac{1-w_F \eta_F}{1-w_F}$
Theoretically, we could also derive a cross-price elasticity for food demand using the homogeneity property: $\varepsilon_F + \varepsilon_{NF} + \eta_F = 0$, and then further get the elasticities for non-food using symmetry etc. but this probably does not make sense if we don't have a price index of NF in the demand equation.

item.title: Estimating the Frisch parameter (flexibility of money)
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
In Sadoulet & de Janvry (1997: 37), the Frisch parameter is calculated from the expenditure elasticity $latex \eta_i$, own-price elasticity $latex E_{ii}$, and the budget share $latex w_i$ for a single food item i:
$latex \omega = \frac{\eta_i(1-w_i \eta_i)}{E_{ii}+w_i \eta_i}$
They suggest "This is commonly done using the food group since it is the one for which prior knowledge of these elasticities tends to be most reliable."
The Frisch parameters calculated from the urban and rural Working-Leser food demand regressions are -0.89 for urban and -1.57 for rural households. These values seem rather low, in particular to the -5.85 reported in an earlier GTAP version.

item.title: Government income compensation for tariff revenue loss
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Because the provision of public goods and services by the government is not captured in the CGE and MS models, a loss in government income would cause a welfare and possibly income decrease which passes unmeasured. Thus, the tariff revenue loss must be compensated through another tax. A new tax could be introduced to counteract increasing inequality or the like but we only want to measure the impacts of the EPA and thus aim at an income distribution neutral tax. The usual instrument for this is a uniform income tax which is equi-proportional. Other taxes, like VAT, might favor the poor but do influence the comparison of different tariff shocks. In the IFPRI CGE model, direct tax on institutions is formulated: 
TINSDEF(INSDNG)..
 TINS(INSDNG) =E= tinsbar(INSDNG)*(1 + TINSADJ*tins01(INSDNG))
 + DTINS*tins01(INSDNG);
To enable a uniform direct tax for all households the DTINS variable is made flexible and the parameter  tins01(INSDNG) is set to 1 for all households and 0 otherwise. The disposable income of the households is then calculated 
(1 - TINS(INSDNG)) * YI(INSDNG))
DTINS causes a uniform percentage point change to the tax. This is the IFPRI standard government closure 2. Microsimulation: In the household data, as direct taxes we classify income tax, property tax, and graduated tax as given in section 14D of the socio-economic survey. Direct tax is applied to total income of each household and the initial tax rate is calculated by sum(direct taxes payed)/total income.

item.title: Measuring poverty
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
A household is classified as poor if its consumption expenditure falls below the poverty line.
Gini: In the non-behavioral microsimulation model consumption expenditure only changes due to prices but important is the budget constraint so that measuring at income makes more sense. However, should income be also scaled downwards to match expenditure or should we allow for savings? We assume that consumption is decisive and the appropriate measure for poverty and thus also scale down so that we can use income growth and after-simulation income to calculate the Gini.
Adult equivalent scales: Appleton (2001) Table A4.2 presents adult equivalent scales based on the caloric needs depending on sex and age . Using these would probably smooth out the distribution. Currently, the Gini is around 0.45 while in the official report to the UNHS05 it is around 0.40.

item.title: Treatment of autoconsumption as income
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
With regard to welfare, autoconsumption should be unaffected by price changes. As we have chosen to also project quantity changes in production of goods, the only choice that will leave autoconsumption consistent with the consumption side is to assume that the quantity of autoconsumption grows proportionately with production. Otherwise the case might arise that production decreases and does not even cover the amount of autoconsumption any more. The same applies to consumption from gifts received in kind. What is a reasonable assumption how autoconsumption changes when production changes?
  • The problem is, that any quantity treatment on the income side might create inconsistencies on the consumption side, e.g. when production of A decreases the consumption of A might need reduction as well.
  • Thus, we should try to separate autoconsumption out: to keep autoconsumption income neutral, it can stay valued at t=0 prices.
Model for household income from agricultural and non-agricultural household enterprise activities: $latex \begin{array}{rl}Y'&=\frac{Y'_M + Y'_H}{CPI}\\Y'_M&=\sum_i \Delta p_{Fi} \Delta {q}_{i} y_{Mi}\\Y'_H&=\sum_i \Delta {q}_{i} y_{Hi}\\CPI&=\frac{\sum_i \Delta p_{Mi} (1-\gamma_i) c_i + \sum_i \gamma_i c_i}{\sum_i c_i}\\ y_{Hi}&=\gamma_i c_i\\ \end{array} $ $latex \Delta q_i$: change in quantity produced, $latex \Delta p_{Mi}$ and $latex \Delta p_{Fi}$: change in market and farm-gate prices, $latex y_{Mi}, y_{Hi}$: marketed income and home consumed income, $latex \Delta q_i=\frac{q'_i}{q_i}$: change in quantity, $latex c_i$: value of consumption of i in market prices, $latex \gamma_i$: share of home consumption in total consumption, $latex \Delta (\cdot)=\frac{(\cdot)'}{(\cdot)}$: change in value of $latex (\cdot)$, and $latex (\cdot)'$: denotes simulated values from CGE results.

item.title: Regional disaggregation of imports in IFPRI standard CGE
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
In order to analyze the issue of trade diversion, imports have to be disaggregated by source region. To this end, the standard Armington formulation in the model, which aggregates imports and domestic production of a commodity, is complemented with an additional, higher-level CES function. This CES function aggregates commodity imports from different origins to a composite imported commodity that is then used in the standard Armington function.
$latex QM_{c} = \alpha^{qm}_c \cdot \left(\sum_{r \in R} \delta^{qm}_{cr}\cdot QMR_{cr}^{-\rho^{qm}_{c}}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\rho^{qm}_c}} \forall c \in CMR$
$latex PMR_{cr} = PM_c \cdot QM_c\left(\sum_{r' \in R} \delta^{qm}_{cr'}\cdot QMR_{cr'}^{-\rho^{qm}_{c}}\right)^{-1} \delta^{qm}_{cr} \cdot QMR_{cr}^{-\rho^{qm}_c-1}\;\forall c \in CMR, r \in R$
$latex PMR_{c r} = pwmr_{cr} \cdot (1+tmr_{cr}) \cdot EXR + \sum_{c' \in CT}PQ_{c'}\cdot icm_{c'c}\;\forall c \in CMR, r \in R$
where $latex \mathit{CMR}$: set of regionally disaggregated imported commodities, $latex R$: set of regions with disaggregated imports, $latex \mathit{PMR}_{cr}, \mathit{QMR}_{cr}, \mathit{tmr}_{cr}$: domestic price, quantity, and import tariff rate of imported commodity $latex c$ from region $latex r$, $latex \delta^{qm}_{cr}, \rho^{qm}_c$: share parameter and function exponent for CES aggregation of imports of commodity $latex c$ from different origins $latex r$.
Equation 1 is the 2nd level CES function, equation 2 the first order condition for the optimum combination of imports from different regions derived from a CES function. Eq. 3 defines the domestic import price for each commodity and region accounting for different border prices and import tariffs. Finally, Equation 3 defines the price of the aggregate import commodity.
For paper:
\begin{align} \mathit{PMR}_{cr} &= \mathit{PM}_c \cdot \mathit{QM}_c\left(\sum_{r' \in R} \delta^{qm}_{cr'}\cdot \mathit{QMR}_{cr'}^{-\rho^{qm}_{c}}\right)^{-1} \delta^{qm}_{cr} \cdot \mathit{QMR}_{cr}^{-\rho^{\mathit{qm}}_c-1} \; & \forall c \in \mathit{CMR}, r \in R\\ \mathit{PMR}_{c r} &= \mathit{pwmr}_{cr} \cdot (1+\mathit{tmr}_{cr}) \cdot \mathit{EXR} + \sum_{c' \in \mathit{CT}}\mathit{PQ}_{c'}\cdot \mathit{icm}_{c'c} \; & \forall c \in \mathit{CMR}, r \in R\\ \mathit{PM}_c \cdot \mathit{QM}_c &= \sum_{r} \mathit{PMR}_{cr} \cdot \mathit{QMR}_{cr} \; & \forall c \in \mathit{CMR} \end{align}

item.title: Re-exports in CGE models
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Re-exports pose a problem in CGE models (e.g., GTAP and IFPRI) because imports usually do not pass into the equation of quantity available for transformation between domestic and export use. As on a perfectly competitive market there is only one price on the world market, the price for the import and export would be equal and thus there is no incentive for performing the re-export. However, re-exports occur in the data. The literature suggests 2 approaches to deal with this problem
  1. Adjustment of the imports and exports of such sector in the SAM: Under the above conditions where re-exporting makes no economic sense, adjust imports and exports in the SAM does not change the economic results. Imports and exports are adjusted by the same amount to keep the SAM balanced. The approach suggested, e.g. on the GTAP web page, computes the adjustment value as follows: $latex RX_i = \frac{M_i}{M_i+P_i} \cdot X_i$ (In general, the following identity holds for each commodity in the SAM: M + P = A + X) where M: imports, P: production, X: exports, RX: re-exports, A: domestic absorption. If available, it is of course better to use some known share of re-exports instead of the M/(M+P) approximation.
  2. Introducing a re-export sector: As suggested in the documentation of the IFPRI standard CGE model (Loefgren, 2001), it can make sense to introduce a sector which solely imports and then exports all of its output (activity and commodity). However, this only makes sense if there is some value addition happening between the importing and exporting of this product. Indeed, in its standard formulation, the IFPRI model does not allow for activities which do not use any primary factors.

item.title: Agricultural household income in CGE
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Income from agricultural sectors is transmitted to households through factor returns. Returns to a particular factor can differ by sector but such differences are usually exogenous. In case of changing factor employment levels, all households get their fixed share of the factor income.
The main missing link in terms of agricultural household income in the CGE-microsimulation framework is the supply and use of specific land. The CGE model does not keep track of whose land is used for what crop because land is assumed to be 1) homogenous, 2) spatially indifferentiated (all land can be used for every purpose). Moreover, "switching" -- putting land type to use for a crop for which it has not been used before -- is difficult to model in a CGE context. Hence, declaring each household's land as one land type is difficult.
Considering the top-down CGE-MS approach, generating a consistent MS scenario from the CGE results is also difficult. In the case of variable labor but fixed land supply, there is no obvious way to impose the CGE results on the household data. Price changes can be projected but quantity changes pose a problem. The CGE results show shifts in land use between crops but which household produces more of the crops, which less, or which do switch crops? This can be only determined in a household level optimization problem. The household optimizes factor returns considering primary and intermediate inputs as well as other factors such risk, know-how, and price information and given constraints, in particular on availability of inputs.

item.title: Trade creation and trade diversion under the Armington assumption
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The original definition of trade diversion as given in Wikipedia:
Trade diversion is an economic term related to international economics in which trade is diverted from a more efficient exporter towards a less efficient one by the formation of a free trade agreement.
However, this definition does not allow for differentiated products as assumed by the Armington assumption. An alternative definition for this case is given in Trading blocs: alternative approaches to analyzing preferential trade agreements  (Jagdish N. Bhagwati,Pravin Krishna,Arvind Panagariya, 1999. Chapter by Deardorff & Stern: 408)
Any time there is substitution away from one good in favor of another as a result of distorted price signals that incorrectly reflect costs, there will tend to be a welfare reduction. If the two goods are both imported, then this substitution may usefully be labeled as trade diversion, for the welfare loss is from the same source as in the simpler, more familiar example.

item.title: Re Uganda Armington elasticities
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Contemplating the utilization of either the GTAP elasticities or the ones given by Vollmer et al. (2009), I tend to decide for the GTAP elasticities. The selling advantage of the Vollmer ones is that they are specifically estimated for Uganda. The big disadvantage is that they are estimated for the 10 one digit chapters of the HS nomenclature. Thus, very heterogeneous products are lumped together which necessarily results in low price variability (important for estimation) and low import demand reactions, as this is an average of many very different products which by no means are required to move together and which probably are not linked by any close relationship (intermediates, substitutes, complements...).
However, I will use the Vollmer elasticities as a case for sensitivity analysis.

item.title: CAP reform and decoupled subsidies
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Breen et al. (2008) list these as the total sources of subsidies received by Irish farmers:
  • single farm payments (SFP)
  • disadvantaged area and rural environmental protection scheme (REPS)
  • forestry premia
  • environmentally sensitive area payments
  • installation aid
  • TB compensation
They say the SFP is by far the largest chunk and all but the first two are of minor importance. Breen et al. (2008) state statistics that the majority of farms in Ireland produce beef at a loss under the single farm payment (SFP). They list potential reasons for this. The most interesting one is that the growing of cattle might be "a cost-effective means of covering their compliance costs". In order to be eligible for the SFP, the farmer has to maintain land and buildings to comply and this cost would still incur when the farmer stopped animal production. These fixed costs are covered by the SFP and thus can be deduced from the production costs, so that the proportion of output produced profitably increases from 32% to 76%. Gelan (2006), p. 9:
Cahill  (1997)  differentiates  between  the concepts  of  fully  decoupled  and  effectively  fully  decoupled.  A  policy  scheme  is defined as fully decoupled if it does not influence production decisions of farmers receiving payments and that it allows free market determination of prices. This is the more restrictive form of decoupling also requiring, in addition to no changes in equilibrium  price  and  quantities,  that  demand  and  supply  functions  remain unchanged when the policy scheme is introduced and with no difference in the response  of  the  market  to  any  exogenous  shock  arising  on  the  demand  or  the supply  side.  On  the  other  hand,  a  policy  scheme  is  defined  as  effectively  fully decoupled  if  it  results  in  production  that  does  not  exceed  the  level  that  would exist without it. That is, production decisions by farmers could be affected by the policy  scheme  but  in  a  way  that  does  not  result  in  larger  production,  although supply responses to external shock would be different with and without the policy regime (Cahill, 1997; OECD, 2001).
Gelan & Schwarz (2008) model the SFP by a simple transfer from the government to households.

item.title: CGE - allowing activities to shut down
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Komen & Peerlings (2001) show in their paper how to model a sector which might shut down based on a simple 1-level Leontief production function.
The CES function probably causes problems in this context since the quantities included on the left hand side might not become zero.
In the case of Corina's Ireland SAM, the calves and sheep sectors will become unprofitable if subsidies are cut. However, these sectors cannot be shut down completely since the output is used also as input for other sectors which in turn cannot become zero. And these outputs are also included in the Armington and export CET functions which also will cause problems.
Moreover, it is not realistic that the sector shuts down completely. As reported in Breen et al. (2008), there are farms with profitable production in those sectors which might even expand once the subsidies and consequently land prices fall. Thus, it might be more realistic to disaggregate such a sector into several sectors with different production technology of which some might shut down, but not all. One shortcoming of this approach is that it basically must be exogenously predetermined which farms shut down / which farms work unprofitable. But factors will move into other sectors in any case and it might not be a real problem.

item.title: Mixed complementarity programming (MCP)
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
We define a variable z>=0 and a function F(z)>=0. The complementarity condition demands that exactly one of these inequalities is fulfilled as an equality, i.e. either z=0 and F(z)>0 or F(z)=0 and z>0 thus z*F(z)=0 will hold in the solution. The complementarity formulation is written like $latex 0 \le z \perp F(z) \ge 0$ (note that the variable and the function are always on the "great than" side of the inequality) The complementarity problem is to find a subset of n inequalities which are satisfied as equalities from a set of 2n inequalities. Each inequality function is matched by a variable with a lower bound. Each equality function is matched by a free (unbounded) variable. S. Wing explains the intuition behind the complementary slackness variables in terms of a CGE model in "computable general equilibrium models for the analysis of economy-environment interactions" In a CGE model there are 3 times of conditions to be satisfied (based on "moving from static to dynamic general equilibrium models" (paltsev, 2004):
  1. zero profit
  2. market clearance
  3. income balance
In terms of MCP formulation:
  1. zero profit: $latex -\textit{profit}\ge 0, y\ge 0, \textit{output} \perp (-\textit{profit}) = 0$
  2. market clearance: $latex \textit{supply}-\textit{demand}\ge 0, p\ge 0, p \perp (\textit{supply} -\textit{demand}) = 0$
  3. income balance: $latex \textit{income}=\textit{endowment}+ \textit{tax revenue}$ In contrast to the first 2 conditions, the income balance does not exhibit complementarity slackness

item.title: Cost function of a production function
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The cost function for a production function returns the input cost for a given level of output, ie. it is a function only dependent of the variable output and the parameters of the production function and the factor prices.
From a production function, set up the minimizing cost problem subject to the production function f(factor use of i).
min C=sum_i(factor rent of i*factor use of i) s.t. Y=f(factor use of i)
Formulate as a Lagrange problem:
min L = sum_i(factor rent of i*factor use of i) + lambda*(Y-f(factor use of i)
Derive the first order conditions and solve for each factor (solve the derivatives wrt. the factors first, put into derivative wrt. labmda, solve for the factor which then should yield a function for the factor which is independent of other factors but dependent on the output).
Put the equations for the factors into the cost function C and simplify.
