item.title: Shocking a single-country CGE model with GTAP results
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
This is from Horridge & Zhai (2005) "Chapter 3 Annex A: Shocking a single-country CGE model with export prices and quantities from a global model" (in: Hertel el al (eds.) "Poverty and the WTO: Impacts of the Doha Development Agenda". See also :Horridge, J. M. & Ferreira Filho, J. (2003). Linking gtap to national models: Some highlights and a practical approach. 6th Annual Conference on Global Economic Analysis, Scheveningen, Holland.
Since supply and demand of an export commodity are endogenous in a global model like GTAP, the world price change of the export is not a good proxy for how demand actually changes. Depending on the slopes of the supply and demand curves, an increasing world export price could be accompanied by increasing or decreasing demand. The GTAP export demand curve is
$latex Q = \left(\frac{FP}{P}\right)^{ESUBM}$
with Q: export demand quantity, P: export price of domestic goods (incl. export tax), FP: curve "shifter" parameter, and ESUBM: elasticity of substitution of imports from different origins from GTAP.
Horridge suggests to adapt the export demand curve of the single country model by calculating the shock on FP from the GTAP gesults and transmitting this. Changes in Q and P come from the GTAP results, ESUBM is also taken from the GTAP model.
The change % change in FP is calculated:
$latex fp=100*\left[ (1+0.01 p)\cdot \left((1+0.01 q)^{1/ESUBM}\right)-1\right]$
where fp, p, and q are percentage changes.
To integrate this approach into the IFPRI Standard CGE, the CET function, which converts products for being for the domestic vs. foreign market, has to be replaced by the simple downward sloping curve above.
The new export demand function does not distinguish between products for the domestic and foreign markets and thus the domestic supply price is now equal to the domestic price of the exported commodity. Instead, the world price of exports becomes endogenous to the model. Because the good is the same whether sold domestically or exported to some region, there can be a separate export demand function for each export region and the total quantity is obtained by simply summing up.
Horridge & Zhai (2005: 95) mention that in the case of a downward sloping export demand function "... export expansion will be accompanied by falling export prices and a TOT loss. Indeed, at modest tariff levels, this TOT loss will dominate the efficiency gains obtained from unilateral tariff reduction and aggregate welfare will fall."

item.title: Keep the total amount of subsidies equal
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
In the case of CAP subsidies from the EU, the total amount is usually fixed per sector so that if production in the sector in-/decreases, the total amount of subsidy does not change with it.
To implement this in the IFPRI Standard CGE model, the particular tax rate, for this example the tax on activity output TA, is split into two parts: a flexible and a fixed part. The fixed part (TAconst) is the usual (positive) tax rate on activity output. The flexible part (TAVAR) is a tax rate (negative for a subsidy) which adapts so that the total amount of the subsidy is kept fixed. The total TA tax rate is then
TA(A) = taconst(A) + TAVAR(A)
Thus, TA and TAVAR are variables and taconst is a parameter.
Another equation has to be added to vary TAVAR according to the fixed amount of subsidy (tafixval):
tafixval(A) = TAVAR(A) * PA(A) * QA(A)
Moreover, TAVAR should be forced to equal zero whenever tafixval is zero to avoid perverse results if - for some reason - PA or QA are zero.

item.title: Allocating household factor income to SAM activities
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: In order to obtain consistency between the factor incomes of the households and the actual factor usage of the activities, I try to derive the actual sector of activity for the factor incomes. As a general guideline, I have to assume that the household survey captures all income sources and thus also returns from non-household enterprises. Wage labor income is actually the only reliable separated factor available in the supply use tables and from the household survey, the exact sector of wage workers in particular in terms of crop sectors cannot be derived. Thus, wage incomes will be taken from the supply use tables and the inflated to the observed level of wage incomes from the household survey. Self-employment incomes necessarily are based on imputed values. For labor, these are derived as follows. All self-employed unskilled labor is valued at the median wage of the 25% poorest of the rural or urban population, respectively. This is assumed to proxy the subsistence wage at which there is an unlimited supply of labor available. These subsistence labor returns are derived for male, female, and children separately. The UNHS 2005/06 allows to separate total hours worked of a household into crop, wage, and other labor, distinguished by person type (male, female, children) and skill level (skilled and unskilled). The skill level is based on the ISCO classification given for each individual in the household survey. All people with an occupation classification in general groups 1 to 3 are classified as "skilled", all others as "unskilled". Self-employed labor income from crop work. The hours of crop work per person type are given on a plot level for each household and for each plot the shares of the plot area planted with a particular crop. This information is used to split the total crop labor into the shares used per crop type. All crop workers are assumed to be unskilled. Self-employed land income. The imputed land rents are based on the observed in cash median rent per acre within a district.  The land area employed per crop by a household can be derived from the areas for parcels and plot use and crop shares given in the agricultural questionnaire of the UNHS. Self-employed labor income from non-agricultural household enterprises and livestocks. The share of labor hours for non-agricultural household enterprises and livestock growing is known in total (Derived as the residual hours from total household working hours minus crop and wage work hours.). The various household enterprises are associated to industrial sectors by ISIC codes. For livestock, the particular animals are given. There is no information on livestock labor hours and only rough information on the identity of household members involved in the business so that no stock of actual hours worked in the various businesses can be taken. Hence, I opt for the practical approach of allocating labor by the enterprise's share in total gross revenue. (Valued added by enterprise would be a better measure. However, the value added for some enterprises is negative and in general, for imputing household self-employment factor incomes, I assumed that all household factors have to be employed at their subsistence rate. Later, this is modified and scaled down so we cannot work with the subsistence rates here). There is only a total value for livestock revenue included first. In a succeeding step, livestock is split into the three SAM categories cattle, poultry and other livestock by using their respective shares in total herd value. Another round of imputation is necessary where households have non-agricultural or livestock enterprises but none with non-zero revenue. In this case all listed enterprises will get assigned equal shares.

Surplus labor
  • according to A. Lewis, "...defined as that part of the labor force that can be removed without reducing the total amount of output produced, even when the input of other factors remains constant."
  • marginal product of laborers in the subsistence sector is zero (at least below the subsistence wage)
  • industry is assumed to pay a margin over the agricultural subsistence wage which needs to offset costs of relocation, increased cost of living, etc.
  • industry will employ labor so that the marginal product of labor is equal the wage rate.
  • as long as there is surplus labor in ag, industry can draw in additional labor at the same wage rate.
  • through reinvestment of profits, the marginal rate of return to capital increases and more labor is drawn into industry
  • once surplus labor is exhausted, industry and agricultural wages increase.

item.title: Upward-sloping labor supply curve
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Supply for factors might be dependent on the level of the real factor returns or wage. Thus, if the real wage increases, the factor supply increases as well. This can be formulated as follows:
$latex \frac{QFS_f}{QFS0_f} = \left( \frac{\frac{YF_f}{QFS_f} \cdot \frac{CPI0}{CPI}}{\frac{YF0_f}{QFS0_f}} \right)^{\epsilon_f} $
Thus, the factor supply QFS is determined by real average wage to initial average wage ratio and with $latex \epsilon_f $: elasticity of factor supply with respect to wage.

item.title: Modeling dairy quota
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Valuable references:
  • the agenda 2000 CAP reform, world prices and GATT-WTO export constraints (meijl02)
  • On the European Responsibility in the Agricultural Multilateral Trade Negotiations - Modelling the Impacts of the Common Agricultural Policy (femenia09)
  • Abolition of Raw Milk Quota in the European Union - A CGE Analysis at the Member Country Level (lips05)
The quota drives a wedge between the producer (ps) and the market price (pm) where the rent accrues to the producer (pm = ps*(1+tau)). The quota can be seen as a function with two regimes:
  • If the quota is not binding, there is no wedge and the quota rent is zero
  • If the quota is binding, the quota rent can be seen as a tax which adapts endogenously to keep the output constant. In order to realistically depict the income distribution impacts, these rents should accrue to the dairy farm households and thus should involve a transfer to such households.
Magnitude of rent: A main problem is that additionally the current size of the quote rent tau needs to be known. The above references cite some sources for such values which are around 20%. In van Meijl & van Tongeren (2002), the milk quota is model as an MCP as follows: Remaining quota allowance: $latex y = \bar{q} - q $ market price: $latex pm=ps(1+\tau)$ value of quota rent: $latex \tau \cdot ps \cdot q$ and the complementarity condition: $latex \tau \ge 0 \perp y \ge 0 $ with $latex \bar{q}:$ quota, q: output, $latex \tau$: quota rent.

item.content:encoded:
Indirect utility function v:
$latex \ln v = \left[\left(\frac{\ln m - \ln a(P)}{b(P)}\right)^{-1} + \lambda(P)\right]^{-1}$
with $latex \ln a(P) = \alpha_0 + \sum_{k \in I} \alpha_k \ln p_k + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k \in I} \sum_{l \in I} \gamma_{kl} \ln p_k \ln p_l$ $latex b(P) = \prod_{k \in I} p_{k}^{\beta_k}$ $latex \lambda(P)=\sum_{k \in I} \lambda_k \ln p_k$ where $latex \sum_{k \in I} \lambda_k=0$
The corresponding cost function (solve the indirect utility function for m) is:
$latex \ln m = \frac{b(P)}{\frac{1}{\ln v}-\lambda(P)} + \ln a(P)$
or
$latex C(v,P) = exp\left( \frac{b(P)}{\frac{1}{v}-\lambda(P)}\right)\cdot a(P)$
with v: indirect utility, m: income.
Also to be found in: * decoster98: better formula is on page 7, eq (17).

item.title: Calculate real income when demand system is used to change prices
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
1. Compute new nominal income: $latex Y_N'=\sum_{i \in I} y_i p_i $ where I is the set of agricultural incomes or food items
  2. Calculate $latex v^0$ using the QUAIDS indirect utility function
  3. calculate the cost of same utility $latex v^0$ under new price vector using the QUAIDS cost function: $latex c^1 = c(v^0, P^1)$
  4. The "price index" is then $latex \Delta c = \frac{c^1}{m}$
  5. The new real income is $latex Y_R' = \frac{Y_N'}{\Delta c}$

item.title: Slutsky Equation
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The Slutsky equation splits the change in demand for a good resulting from a price change into an income and a substitution effect. In other words, it relates the Marshallian (uncompensated) and Hicksian (compensated) demand.
Marshallian demand $latex X^M(P, m)$ with $latex P$: vector of prices, m: expenditure
Hicksian demand $latex X^H(P, u)$ with u: utility
Marshallian demand maximizes utility given a fixed budget while Hicksian demand minimizes the cost to reach a given utility level.
Marshallian and Hicksian demand are equal if the budget m equals the cost to attain the utility level u, thus
$latex X^M(P, m) = X^H(P, u)$
s.t.
$latex m = C(P, u)$
Hence
$latex X^M(P, C(P, u)) = X^H(P, u)$
respectively, demand for a single good
$latex x_i^M(P, C(P, u)) = x_i^H(P, u)$
Now, deriving both sides with respect to $latex p_i$:
$latex \frac{\partial x_i^M}{\partial p_i} + \frac{\partial x_i^M}{\partial m} \cdot \frac{\partial C}{\partial p_i} = \frac{\partial x_i^H}{\partial p_i}$
Substituting in Roy's Identity (relates Marshallian demand for a good to some indirect utility function $latex V(P, m)$)
$latex \frac{\partial C(P, u) }{\partial p_i} = - \frac{\frac{\partial V(P, C(P, u))}{\partial p_i}}{\frac{\partial V(P, C(P, u))}{\partial m}} = x_i^M(P, m)$
(No, actually not Roy's Identity but only the optimality condition for demand, i.e., the first order partial derivative of the cost function w.r.t. price is equal to the demand for i.)
gives
$latex \frac{\partial x_i^M}{\partial p_i} + \frac{\partial x_i^M}{\partial m} \cdot x_i^M = \frac{\partial x_i^H}{\partial p_i}$
and rearranging results in the Slutsky equation:
$latex \frac{\partial x_i^M}{\partial p_i} = \underbrace{\frac{\partial x_i^H}{\partial p_i} }_{\text{substitution effect}} - \underbrace{\frac{\partial x_i^M}{\partial m} \cdot x_i^M}_{\text{income effect}}$
The substitution effect measures the change in demand resulting from the change in the exchange rate between the good while the income effect measures the change in demand which is caused by the change in purchasing power.
The Slutsky equation in elasticity terms:
$latex \epsilon_{ij} = \epsilon_{ij}^{H} - w_j \cdot \eta_i$

item.title: Calculate equivalence variation from demand equations
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded: The goal is to derive welfare changes according to a demand system when income or prices change. Thus, either the utility (or cost) function associated to the demand system has to be recovered or an approximation to be found. Recovering the utility function requires at some point integration of parts of the demand system and this is named the "integrability problem" as this recovery using integration is only possible under certain conditions. Moreover, this can be a very complex task, in particular, if more than one good is involved (Creedy, 2006). However, Vartia (1983) has introduced a general method which can calculate CV numerically when only the Marshallian demand functions are known. Discussion of this approach are also included in Bacon (1995), Dumagan and Mount (1997) or Creedy (2006). More general extensions of Vartia (1983) to non-market goods in Bullock & Minot (2006) and Ebert (2010). Readings: empirical approaches to the measurement of welfare (slesnick98) the integrability problem (border03) topics in consumer theory (jehle) algorithm to find money metric utility: Efficient Methods of Measuring Welfare Change and Compensated Income in Terms of Ordinary Demand Functions (vartia83) alleged improvement of Vartia algorithm (but no citations?!): Approximating compensated income from ordinary demand functions (dumagan97) More simple discussion of the Vartia approach: How to Calculate Welfare Measures Using Only Marshallian Demand Functions (creedy06) Extensions to non-market goods: On Measuring the Value of a Nonmarket Good Using Market Data (bullock06) On the Measurement of Welfare for Market and Nonmarket Goods - A Numerical Approach (ebert10)

item.title: Vartia algorithm to calculate compensation variation from Marshallian demand equations
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Basics of the Vartia algorithm

This is the algorithm for calculating CV for before - after price vectors (P0, P1) from only Marshallian demand equations devised by Vartia (1983) in the notation close to Creedy (2006). The basis for the procedure is given by an application of Shephard's Lemma and the relationship between Hicksian and Marshallian demands (the change in expenditure to retain the initial utility level upon a price increase is equal to the quantity consumed): $$\frac{d E(p, U)}{d p_i} = x^M(p, E(p, U))$$ In discrete form (differences on the left hand side and the arithmetic mean on the right): $$\frac{\Delta E}{\Delta p} = \frac{E_1 - E_0}{p_1 - p_0}= 0.5 \cdot [x_0(p_0,E_0) + x_1(p_1,E_1)]$$ with $$E_t = E(p_t,U_0)$$.
$$\Rightarrow E_1 = E_0 + 0.5 \cdot (x_0(p_0,E_0) + x_1(p_1,E_1))(p_1 - p_0)$$ Remember: $$x_1=x_1(p_1, E_1)$$, i.e. x1 depends on E1! Thus, the task is to find a quantity where $$E_1$$ is equal on both sides. Example pseudo code algorithm for one commodity:
  1. cut the price change from p0 to p1 in a number of equally sized steps
  2. set current budget E_1 = m_0
  3. for each price step k:
    • a. calculate demand x(p_k, E_1)
    • b. calculate E_1' = the trapezoid area to the left of the demand curve and between the p_{k-1} and p_k lines + E_1 to approximate the CV
    • c. if |E_1 - E_1'| < epsilon then goto 4.
    • d. E_1 = E_1'
    • e. got 3.a.
  4. next k

The algorithm

After execution, E_{N+1} contains the compensated demand, i.e., CV = E_{N+1} - m0.
E_{N+1} is expenditure E(p1, u0) which is the Hicksian or compensated demand. Remember, CV is the amount of money a person need to be compensated by to remain on the initial indifference curve. During the procedure, m is held constant so that m=E(p0, u0)=E(p1,u1). The equivalent variation EV which can be calculated from E(p0, u1) is calculated by performing the procedure backwards from price vector p1 to vector p0 (see Creedy, 2006). 
m0: expenditure in t=0
Q0_i: demand for good i in t=0
P0_i, P1_i: price for good i in t=0 and t=1, respectively
N: number of price steps (=generating N+1 prices)
E_n: approximate expenditure for price step n
$$i in I$$: set of goods
QFN(P,m): demand function

E_1 = m0
FOR ALL i IN I { Q_i = Q0_i }
FOR n=1 TO N+1
   FOR ALL i IN I { P_{i,n} = P0_i + (n-1)/N*(P1_i - P0_i) }
NEXT n
FOR n=2 TO N+1
   E_n = E_{n-1}
   REPEAT
      e = E_n
      FOR ALL i in I
         Q_{i,n} = QFN_i(P_{i,n}, e)
      NEXT i
      E_n = E_{n-1} + 1/2*sum_{ALL i IN I}{(Q_{i,n}+Q_{i,n-1})*(P_{i,n}-P_{i,n-1})}
   UNTIL ABS(e - E_n) <= delta
NEXT n

References

  • Error Analysis and Comparison of Two Algorithms Measuring Compensated Income (sun12):
    examines error of Vartia procedure, graphical exposition of algorithm
  • Creedy 2006
  • Vartia 1983

Try of explanation for high domestic activity increase: The world market price for the export cprfd is shocked by an 8.5% increase. The optimality condition resulting from the CET export function, relates the optimal ratio of quantities between production for the export and domestic markets to the relative price between exports and products for the domestic market via an elasticity $$\epsilon = 2.5$$. \[\frac{QE}{QD}=\left(\frac{PE}{PDS}\right)^\epsilon \cdot \left(\frac{1-\delta}{\delta}\right)^\epsilon\] Ceteris paribus, with a 10% increase of PE the price ratio PE/PDS increases by 10% and $$(\frac{PE}{PDS})^\epsilon=1.1^2.5=1.27$$ would result in a change of the ratio of QE over QD of 27%. As all prices are measured against the numeraire CPI in which cprfd has a share of 6.4%, the prices of intermediates for cprfd production decrease by about 0.5%. This effect outweighs the increase of factor prices so that cprfd supply prices decrease, stimulating domestic demand. item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
In ODI CAP-liberalization CGE model, real government expenditures and real investment as well as foreign savings are fixed and non-governmental institutions, foremost households, have to adapt their savings in order to offset changes in the prices of government expenditures and investment and in the value of foreign savings changed by the exchange rate.
In order to exclude the effect of "borrowing from the future" from the poverty results, poverty is measured by consumption excluding savings. Changes in savings only occur through the above price or exchange rate changes.

The big points to do:
  1. Which price shock to use?
  2. Household to geographic market mapping.
  3. How to deal with autoconsumption?
Ad 3.:
  • Embrace assumption from my QUAIDS estimation that the household is able to freely convert home consumption back and forth to other consumption goods at market prices.
  • Calculate after-price-shock-income of a single household as \[ y_1 = \sum_i(q_{i,0}^N\cdot p_{i,1}^M+q_{i,0}^M \cdot p_{i,0}^M) \cdot \frac{C(P_0^M,u_0)}{C(P_1^M,u_0)} \] with superscript N and M denoting non-marketed (autoconsumption and from gifts received in-kind) and marketed consumption.
    • non-marketed consumption share: \[ s_{i,0}^N = \frac{q_{i,0}^N\cdot p_{i,0}^M}{(q_{i,0}^N\cdot +q_{i,0}^M) \cdot p_{i,0}^M} = \frac{v_{i,0}^N}{v_{i,0}} \]
    • Calculating with values and shares: $$! y_1 = \sum_i\left(s_{i,0}^N\cdot v_{i,0} \cdot \frac{p_{i,1}^M}{p_{i,0}^M}+(1-s_{i,0}^N) \cdot v_{i,0}\right) \cdot \frac{C(P_0^M,u_0)}{C(P_1^M,u_0)} = \sum_i\left(s_{i,0}^N \cdot \frac{p_{i,1}^M}{p_{i,0}^M}+(1-s_{i,0}^N)\right) \cdot v_{i,0} \cdot \frac{C(P_0^M,u_0)}{C(P_1^M,u_0)}$$
  • Steps: 1. revalue autoconsumption with prices p1; 2. calculate cost C1 of attaining utility u0 under market prices p1; 3. calculate deflated income y1.
  • Gifts received in-kind will be treated like autoconsumption because the household does not get to select. Drawback: if prices change, also food received in-kind might be substituted by the donor or its quantity might change.
  • With this calculation, households can have their income increased if prices for their autoconsumption increase relative to their marketed consumption and they substitute away towards marketed consumption. By assumption, they have a larger budget and sell some of their previously autoconsumed to buy other goods from the market.

item.title: Uganda recession impacts (EAAE Turkey paper), discussion with AlanAlan
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The recession shocks is composed of 3 parts:
  1. Import (food & energy/fertilizer) price shock
  2. Export demand and price shock
  3. A shock on inflows of foreign transfers
Ad 1: Reuse R scripts from EAAE Dublin paper to generate world price shock vector.Ad 2: Implement downward-sloping export demand function as in Horridge paper (coupling multi- and single country CGEs).Ad 3: Need to find a sensible shock from data.

Downward-sloping export demand function:

$$Q = \left(\frac{FP}{P}\right)^{ESUBM}$$ with FP being a shift parameter, P the domestic price of exports, and ESUBM the GTAP Armington elasticity (positive; the implied elasticity of the function is thus -ESUBM). If we take ESUBM from GTAP, then with Q and P we can calculate FP as $$FP=Q^{\frac{1}{ESUBM}}\cdot P$$. Moreover, the change in $$\Delta FP = \frac{FP_1}{FP_0} = \left(\frac{Q_1}{Q_0}\right)^{\frac{1}{ESUBM}} \cdot \frac{P_1}{P_0} = {\Delta Q}^{\frac{1}{ESUBM}} \cdot \Delta P$$.

Shock specification:

We are thinking of 5 simulations covering the 2006-08 period:
  1. Food price shocks
  2. Fuel price shocks
  3. Recession (export quantity) shocks (cannot be done separately from 1 and 2)
  4. Foreign transfer (aid, remittances, FDI) shocks
  5. Combined shock

Immediate steps

  • (ole) Modify model and choose export elasticity demand parameters. Re-run Dublin paper food and fuel price shocks on modified model. Simulate illustrate foreign transfer shock (-10%, -20%).
  • (alan) Identify recession and foreign transfer shocks

After further discussion:

  • Horridge-style export demand function shock does not make sense as quantities are a consequence of the prices or vice verca. Too endogenous. We stick with the CET function and price shocks on the export side as well.
  • As the model is medium- to long-run, we are after showing the impacts of the structural change in food prices and the financial crisis. To imitate that, take averages of 2004-2006 and 2008-2010 to calculate shocks.
  • To get deflated trade values, the US GDP deflator from the WDI is used.
  • The trade unit values could be improved by using the Trade Unit Values database by CEPII.
  • The capital inflows shock is split into 3 elements:
    • Aid inflows: shock to government income & government expenditure. Reduce GSAV but what to reduce on gov expenditure side (EG=PQ_c*QG_c + transfers to nongov institutions)? In SAM: gov does not transfer to non-gov institutions and it runs a budget surplus. It spends on administration, health and community services. Reduction of those items in equal proportions seems the only alternative.
    • FDI: shock to FSAV and investment. Reduce investment in real terms using IADJ for each commodity same share.
    • remittances: shock to ROW transfers to households

item.content:encoded: The shocks for the sectors of the SAM are based on unit values (uv) and quantities (q) and calculated with Laspeyres indexes. Why is the economy shrinking with sales tax (ST) replacement instead of expanding as with income levy (IL) replacement?

sector set definitions:

everything with reference to TAREPAST:
  • domestic output:
    • export sectors are expanding but much less than in IL (maybe 1/3)
    • in particular, hotels, as the biggest export sector, is shrinking marginally instead of expanding by 0.55%
    • most import sectors are shrinking more than in IL, few are expanding but less than in IL
    • investment sectors are shrinking more than in IL or shrinking instead of expanding as in IL
  • other changes:
    • sales tax increases by about 0.2 %points on average
    • import tariffs on consumption goods decrease by 0 to 0.02 %points on average
    • consumer prices (PQ) for household consumption goods are largely dropping
Possible explanations (to be tested): a. Positive P effects from lower import tariffs do not reach households as the rising sales tax on household consumption goods overcompensates. Draft explanation:
The EPA scenario where the sales tax is used as the compensatory measure for the loss of government revenue is generally characterized by an economic contraction. The initial tariff reductions have noteworthy impacts only in the sectors for wood & paper products, chemicals & fertilizer, other manufacturing, machinery & equipment, and furniture, which to a large extent feed into investment. In other sectors, the reduction in tariff expenditure in terms of total supply value (domestic+imports) is 0.02% or less. As a large share of the earlier sectors is mainly satisfying demand for investment which is fixed in quantity terms, quantity demand does not react much to the price decrease. In contrast, demand for these products decreases in value terms. On the supply side, the lower import prices lead to reduced producer prices for these goods and thus decrease incentives for production. Apart from this reduction in economy-distorting policy, in this scenario the sales tax is increased by some percentage identical in all sectors to counterbalance the loss in government revenue from the tariff reductions. This policy magnifies the existing distortions and leads to an additional deadweight loss. For the majority of sectors apart from the previously listed investment-linked sectors, the additional sales taxes outweigh the decrease in tariff expenditure by a multitude. Consequently, demand decreases, leading to contractions of these sectors and a higher deadweight loss. Although the economy as a whole and the larger share of the production sectors are shrinking, there is a relative shift from the import-competing and, in particular, the investment sectors toward the major exporting sectors.

item.title: Linear expenditure system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The LES is derived from a Stone-Geary utility function (see Sadoulet & de Janvry, 1995):
$$u = \prod_{i} (q_i - \gamma_i)^{\beta_i}$$ or equivalently $$u = \sum_{i} \beta_i \ln(q_i - \gamma_i)$$
$$p_i, q_i, M, \beta_i, \gamma_i$$: price, quantity, total expenditure, substitution and subsistence (minimum subsistence quantity) parameters, respectively.
$$\beta_i$$'s are the fixed shares (marginal budget shares) in which the "supernumerary" or "uncommitted" income $$(M - \sum_j \gamma_j p_j)$$ is divided across the commodities.
The domains of the parameters are:
$$0< \beta_i < 1 \quad$$ (since $$\beta_i>0$$ the LES does not allow for inferior goods)
$$\sum_i \beta_i = 1$$
$$q_i - \gamma_i \ge 0$$
Interpretation:
$$\beta_i$$: marginal budget share
$$\sum_i \gamma_i p_j$$: subsistence expenditure
$$M - \sum_j \gamma_j p_j$$: supernumerary income
Indirect utility: $$v = (m - \sum_i p_i \gamma_i) \prod_i (\frac{\alpha_i}{p_i})^{\alpha_i}$$ or, as in Pollack & Wales (1992, p. 12, eq. 20): $$v = \dfrac{m - \sum_i p_i \gamma_i}{\prod_i p_i^{\alpha_i}}$$
Expenditure function: $$E(u,p) = \sum_i p_i \gamma_i + u \prod_i (\frac{p_i}{\alpha_i})^{\alpha_i}$$
From maximizing the utility subject to the budget constraint the LES demand function is derived:
LES demand function: $$p_i q_i = p_i \gamma_i + \beta_i (M - \sum_j p_j \gamma_j)$$
The LES demand function implies a linear Engel curve, i.e., varying M (ceteris paribus) q_i increases linearly.
Income (Expenditure) elasticity: $$\eta_i = \frac{\beta_i }{w_i}$$
Own price elasticity: $$\epsilon_{ii} = -1 + (1-\beta_i)\frac{\gamma_i}{q_i}$$
Cross price elasticity: $$\epsilon_{ij} = -\frac{\beta_i \gamma_j p_j}{p_i q_i}, \quad \forall i \neq j$$
with budget share $$w_i = \frac{p_i q_i}{M}$$
See Sadoulet and de Janvry for the elasticity derivations.
Considering the formula for the own price elasticity and the domains of the corresponding parameters: $$-1 \le \epsilon_{ii} \le 0$$, thus demand is always inelastic w.r.t. own prices. The income elasticities are always positive ($$\eta_i \ge 0$$) and thus the LES does not allow for inferior goods. The LES demand is quasi-homothetic as an increase in income has constant marginal budget shares for each product but it is only homothetic in the non-subsistence term of the demand equation. According to the parameter domains, the cross-price elasticities need to be negative and thus all goods are gross complements. By contrast, the compensated cross-price elasticities must be positive and thus all goods are net substitutes.

item.title: Calibrating a CGE model's demand system to elasticities from other sources
item.dc:creator: Ole

What errors are made when using elasticity data from other sources?
1. Aggregation:
* If elasticities are assigned to the SAM commodities, the theoretical demand system properties of adding up, symmetry, and homogeneity are not met any more.
* For commodities where the SAM is more aggregated than the elasticity data, two or more elasticities have to be aggregated as well by value share weighting. But this data is usually not available.
* For commodities where the SAM is less aggregated, two or more commodities are assigned the same elasticity.
* Some commodities have overlapping definitions in either of the two, e.g., in the demand system 'maize' includes the grains, cobs and the flour but in the SAM 'maize' is defined to be only unprocessed maize and 'maize flower' is included in 'processed grains'. There is no clean way to calculate a 'good' elasticity without additional data.
 
Based on: Yu et al. (2003)
The LES has two parameters, $$\beta_i$$: the substitution and $$\gamma_i$$ the subsistence parameters.

item.title: Maximum entropy
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
read: http://daniel-wilkerson.appspot.com/entropy.html Background: I want to calibrate the parameters of a Linear Expenditure System (LES) to my elasticity estimates from a censored QUAIDS. The GTAP project is calibrating its CDE function to literature estimates using a maximum entropy approach, see Liu (1998). Unfortunately, they do not show the model they use.
Principle:
Select the model that satisfy the data but is otherwise least informative (Fraser, 2000 cites Jaynes, 1957).
Select the distribution which satisfies all given constraints and data but has the largest remaining uncertainty otherwise. Thus, all information is used but no additional bias is introduced. The probability distribution that best avoids unnecessary assumptions (Penfield, 2010).
Simple burger meal example is in Penfield (2010), chapter 8 and 9. Given the average price customers pay per meal and the sales prices of the 3 different meal types, ME is used to calculate the probabilities of each meal being bought by a customer. Without any information, one would assume each of the meals has the same probability (uniform distribution), i.e. 1/3. Using ME, the information of the average price is incorporated (and general knowledge about probabilities, i.e., that the sum of the probabilities is one and each probability lies between zero and one) and the probabilities are found which deviate the least from the uniform distribution, i.e. only deviations which are justified by the information available are accepted. The distance for "the least deviation" is measured by the ME measure. The maximum entropy (ME) method is based on information theory (Shannon, 1948). Entropy is a measure for disorder or uncertainty or missing information. From Golan et al. (2001): $$x$$: random variable with possible outcomes $$x_s, s = 1, ... , N$$ with probabilities $$p_s$$ Shannon's entropy measure of a distribution $$P = {p_1 ... p_N}$$ is $$S(P) = - \sum_{s=1}^N p_s \ln p_s$$ where $$0 \ln 0 = 0$$. s.t. $$\sum_s p_s = 1$$: probabilities add up to one The maximum of the function $$S$$ is $$\ln(N)$$ when all $$p_s=1/N$$ and $$S$$ is zero when $$p_s = 1$$ exactly for one $$s$$. By the principle of maximum entropy, among all probability distributions satisfying prior knowledge about the distribution (e.g., constraints or parameters of the distribution), the one that has the largest information entropy (=measure of the uncertainty in a random variable; information uncertainty of a random variable; largest Shannon Entropy measure) is the one that best represents the current state of knowledge. Cross-entropy: if there is not a prior for a single value of the parameter to be estimated but a prior distribution of the parameter, e.g. the sample probability for each household from a household survey. While the maximum entropy measure finds a probability distribution for the support points as close to the uniform distribution as possible considering the constraints, the cross entropy measure finds a probability distribution as close to the prior distribution as possible considering the constraints.
Supports points: (taken from the SAS ENTROPY procedure manual)
"To perform regression, the ENTROPY procedure uses a generalization of maximum entropy called generalized maximum entropy. In maximum entropy estimation, the unknowns are probabilities. Generalized maximum entropy expands the set of problems that can be solved by introducing the concept of support points. Generalized maximum entropy still estimates probabilities, but these are the probabilities of a support point. Support points are used to map the domain of the maximum entropy to the any finite range of values. Prior information, such as expected ranges for the parameters or the residuals, is added by specifying support points for the parameters or the residuals. Support points are points in one dimension that specify the expected domain of the parameter or the residual. The wider the domain specified, the less efficient your parameter estimates are (the more variance they have). Specifying more support points in the same width interval also improves the efficiency of the parameter estimates at the cost of more computation. Golan, Judge, and Miller (1996) show that the gains in efficiency fall off for adding more than five support points."
  • cross entropy web page with some basic info and refs:
    http://support.sas.com/documentation/cdl/en/etsug/60372/HTML/default/viewer.htm#etsug_entropy_sect020.htm

item.title: Walras' Law / adding-up of demand in elasticity terms
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
All budget is spent: $$\sum_i p_i q_i(p,M) = M$$
Differentiate both sides w.r.t. M:
$$ \sum_i {p_i \frac{\partial q_i(p,M)}{\partial M}} = 1$$
Set this identity in relation to the income elasticity of demand $$\eta_i = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial M}\cdot \frac{M}{q_i} $$ by multiplying the above with $$\frac{q_i M}{q_i M}$$:
$$ \sum_i {p_i q_i \over M} \frac{M}{q_i} \frac{\partial q_i(p,M)}{\partial M} = \sum_i w_i \cdot \eta_i = 1$$
Thus, the all budget shares $$w_i$$ times the income elasticities $$\eta_i$$ need to sum up to one.

item.title: Wage curve / labor supply curve
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Implementation of upward sloping labor supply curve based on wage curve

The problems with calibrating the labor supply curves of Berittella-style to unemployed households plus the fact that wage curve relationships are only observed at the macro level, makes me believe that the following approach is more promising. The labor-wage relationship is determined by the Blanchflower & Oswald wage curve, i.e. wages are higher with lower unemployment. This relationship is integrated for the aggregate labor supply curve. But as households have differing availability for additional labor supply (some are unemployed, some underemployed and others fully employed), not all household will offer additional labor. This is implemented by restricting the maximum amount of labor at the household level. An adjustment parameter increases or decreases unemployment by the same percentage point change for all households. It must also be ensured that households cannot supply negative amounts of labor. Household labor supply curve: The model: $$!\begin{array}{rcl} L_{ \sum } & = & \sum_h L_h\\ UERADJ & = & \left( \frac{W/W_0}{CPI / CPI_0} \right)^{\epsilon} - 1\\ UER_h & = & UER_h^0 + UERADJ + UER\_LT0_h - UER\_GT1_h\\ L_h & = & L_h^{max} (1 - UER_h)\\ L_h^{max} \ge L_h &\perp& UER\_LT0_h\ge0\\ UER_h \le 1 &\perp& UER\_GT1_h \ge0 \end{array}$$ Total labor supply $$L_{\sum}$$ is the sum of all household labor supplies. The unemployment rate (UER) adjustment (UERADJ) derives from the wage curve where $$\epsilon$$ is assumed to -0.1. The higher the wage is the lower is unemployment. This affects all individual households' labor supply by an identical percentage point change. But each household's labor supply is limited from above by its full employment and from below by unemployment which is implemented by two complementarity conditions. If a household's labor supply hits the maximum (full employment), then the variable UER_LT0 adjusts to take the value of "overemployment". If the household's labor supply hits zero (no employment), then the variable UER_GT1 adjusts to take on excess unemployment. Hence, as shown in the graph above, the each household's labor supply curve is vertical for wages leading to unemployment rates greater than one and employment rates less than zero. The area of underemployment is governed by the shape of the wage curve.

Household income

Additionally, a household's share in a factor's income is not fixed any more but instead varies according to the household's factor supply. Thus, household's factor income share must be calculated endogenously. Complete changes to model: $$\begin{array}{rclr} QFS_F &=& \sum_H QFSH_{F,H} & \forall F\\ SHIF_{INSD,F} &=& \frac{QFSH_{F,H}}{QFS_F} &\forall INSD,F\\ UERADJ_F & = & \left( \frac{YF_F/QFS_F}{YF0_F/QFS0_F}\cdot \frac{CPI0}{CPI} \right)^{\epsilon} - 1\\ UER_{F,H} & = & uer0_{F,H} + UERADJ_F + UER\_LT0_{F,H} - UER\_GT1_{F,H}\\ QFSH_{F,H} & = & qfshmax_{F,H} \cdot (1 - UER_{F,H})\\ qfshmax_{F,H} \ge QFSH_{F,H} &\perp& UER\_LT0_{F,H} \ge 0\\ UER_{F,H} \le 1 &\perp& UER\_GT1_{F,H} \ge 0 \end{array}$$

Literature and thoughts considered

Wage curve literature:

seminal work: Blanchflower & Oswald 1995 labor supply elasticity pretty stable in developed countries: -0.1 urban labor supply in Ivory Coast (Wages and Unemployment in an Urban African Labour Market (hoddinott96)): -0.12 labor supply elasticity in South Africa (HOW FLEXIBLE ARE WAGES IN RESPONSE TO LOCAL UNEMPLOYMENT IN SOUTH AFRICA?, Kingdon and Knight, 2005): -0.1

Use of labor supply curve in a CGE model:

Not the typical wage curve but some ad hoc specification: Modelling the labour market of minority ethnic groups (berrittella12) A Global Perspective on Effectiveness of Aid for Trade (berrittella12) They use the following labor supply function: $$S = a - \frac{b}{w}$$ where a: asymptote or potential / limit of unskilled labor force available, b: positive parameter, w: real wage. Labor supply elasticity: $$ \epsilon = \frac{b}{a w - b}$$ unemployment rate: $$ u = 1 - \frac{S}{a} $$ Thus, alternative formula for labor supply elasticity: $$\epsilon = \frac{u}{1-u}$$

Considerations regarding Berrittella (2012) approach for Uganda IHH CGE

Simply following the ad hoc approach also used e.g. in Berrittella (2012), i.e., labor supply = $$ s = a - \frac{b}{w} $$ where s, a, w are derived from the household survey in combination with the CGE variable initializations and b is calibrated. Thus, each household has an idiosyncratic labor supply function depending on the real wage. Some remarks:
  • if w tends to zero, labor supply s might get negative => make sure that each household has enough room for a decrease in wage, for example, 10%
  • with this function, household employment can only approach full employment but never reach it => assume that full employment is, e.g., 101% of household's given full employment
  • what about unemployed households, i.e. households with no current labor income? They cannot be calibrated.

item.title: Uganda EPA paper: labor market
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The supplies of unskilled and skilled labor increase with the associated real wage levels based on the so-called wage curve popularized by D. Blanchflower & A. J. Oswald (see Blanchflower and Oswald, 1994). Blanchflower & Oswald found a stable relationship between the level of the real wage and unemployment with an elasticity of unemployment with respect to the real wage level of approximately -0.1. Subsequently, this elasticity has been confirmed by a large number of studies for various countries including the African countries Burkina Faso, Côte d'Ivoire, and South Africa. Nijkamp & Poot (2005) subject the findings of the wage curve literature to a meta-analysis, confirm the stability of the finding of the relationship, and suggest a publication-bias corrected elasticity of -0.07. While the aggregate labor supply is determined by the wage curve, individual households might be limited in their potential to increase or decrease their labor supply. The labor supply of each household is limited from below by no employment and above by full employment. The potential for additional labor supply (un- and underemployment) of the individual households has been derived from the household survey data.

Derivation of potential for additional labor supply

The UNHS provides only limited information on under- and unemployment. The weekly data section is hsec7a is used to derive data on an upper limit of weekly work hours if individuals state that they were not available for more work and their hours worked for the week amounted to less than 40 hours. Questions on unemployment and inactivity (unavailability for work) are also available from section hsec7a. Based on the information from other sections on the hours the household spent on wage work, crop work, and non-agricultural household enterprise activities, an additional labor supply potential was derived by skill levels unskilled and skilled and by person type male, female, and child. Given this data, the labor supply potential was weighted by imputed wages for these different labor supply types. Labor supply is reconciled with the SAM in a subsequent step. This also requires modifying the labor supply potential. On the individual level, the underemployment ratio is preserved for households which have at least some employment. For completely unemployed households, labor supply potential is scaled by the average change in labor potential of the employed households. Afterwards, the aggregate ratio of underemployment to employment is restored by scaling only the non-employed part of the labor supply potential. This is the final outcome of the underemployment rates:

item.title: Vartia approach to calculate compensating variation
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Shephard's Lemma (from Nicholson & Snyder, 2007):

the envelope theorem shows that partial differentiation of the expenditure function with respect to a good’s price yields the demand function for that good. Because utility is held constant in the expenditure function, this demand function will be a compensated one. This result, and a similar one in the theory of the firm, is usually called Shephard’s lemma after the economist who first studied this approach to demand theory in detail. The result is extremely useful in both theoretical and applied microeconomics; partial differentiation of maximized or minimized functions is often the easiest way to derive demand functions. Notice also that the result makes intuitive sense. If we ask how much extra expenditure is necessary to compensate for a rise in the price of good x, a simple approximation would be given by the number of units of x currently being consumed.

item.title: Vartia Uganda - ToDo
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
• Add to paper: The residual term of the regression describes the effects of unobserved determinants and possibly measurement errors.
  • 2-stage QUAIDS CV budget result from "vartia simulate quaids.R" is sometimes greater than that from a simple price mapping: this is due to the way the QUAIDS is simulated. The original system of equations as used for the estimation of the system is also used for the simulations. To reproduce the actual demand of each household as given from the survey data, the equations retain their idiosyncratic residual term which represents effects of unobserved determinants as well as any measurement errors. As the idiosyncratic residual is added to the part of the budget share which is actually determined through estimated parameters of the included determinants, the share can well increase or decrease beyond one or zero, respectively. Consequently, the simulated expenditure shares need to be corrected (1) to lie between 0 and 1 and (2) to add up to one when summed over all items. The second alternative is to calibrate the demand system for each household individually, enforcing the functions to go through the observed data points and to fit the estimated curvature of the functions as good as possible.

item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
These equations loosely follow Jensen et al. (2011). The CDES indirect utility function $$V(P,m)$$:
$$V(P,m) = sum_{i in I} alpha_i left[ {(m/P_i)^{beta_i}-1 over beta_i} right]$$
with
$$alpha_i>0, sum_{i in I} alpha_i = 1, beta_i ge -1, P_i > 0 text{ and } m>0$$ and at most one $$beta_i=-1$$. Budget share form of the CDE Marshallian demand function (p. 224, eq. 22):
$$w_i = {alpha_i (m/P_i)^{beta_i} over sum_{j in I} alpha_j(m/P_j)^{beta_j}}$$ Income elasticity:
$$eta_i = 1 + beta_i - sum_{j in I} w_j beta_j$$
with no restrictions following on the value domain of $$eta_i$$. Own-price elasticity:
$$epsilon_{ii} = -1 - beta_i cdot (1 - w_i)$$
with $$epsilon_{ii} < 0$$. With $$beta_i > 0$$ good i is price elastic, and inelastic otherwise. Cross-price elasticities:
$$epsilon_{ij} = beta_j w_j$$ and $$epsilon_{ji} = beta_i w_i$$
with $$-1 le epsilon_{ij}$$ (Communication with Bjarne Jensen clarified that the <1 restriction from the paper is incorrect.)

Calibration of the CDES parameters

See deBoer09:
Frisch parameter $$varphi_m = sum_{i in I} w_j (beta_j - 1)$$
Reaction parameter $$beta_i = eta_i + varphi_m$$
Preference parameter $$alpha_i = q_i cdot m^{-beta_i} / sum_{j in I} (q_j cdot m^{-beta_j} )$$

item.title: Demand systems: how to specify the error terms for simulation?
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The problem:

Usually, when estimating a demand system, the errors are additive. This is fine if one is only interested in the mean effects of the determinants. However, when simulating individuals whose initial situation (budget shares, income, prices) have to be reproduced, the error term is important as the demand system likely explains only 25% of the variation and 75% are contained in the error terms.
Moreover, when simulating, the error terms have to be adjusted ad-hoc as they can lead to budget shares less than zero or larger one and the sum of the budget shares likely does not add up to one any more.

The idea:

The error terms has to be specified in some multiplicative way so that it gets scaled depending on the budget shares.

Literature:

Additive General Error Models for Production, Cost, and Derived Demand or Share Systems (mcelroy87)

item.title: Four properties of a theoretically consistent demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The 4 general properties of demand:

based on lecture notes by Henneberry
  1. Engel aggregation (adding-up)
  2. Homogeneity of degree zero in income and prices ("absence of money illusion")
  3. Cournot aggregation
  4. Symmetry (matrix of Hicksian substitution effects is symmetric)
Usually homogeneity and symmetry or Cournot aggregation restrictions are imposed. Number of parameters to be estimated for all income and price elasticities: $$n^2+n$$
= $$n$$ own-price + $$n^2-n$$ cross-price + $$n$$ income elasticities Reduction of number of parameters by imposing the general properties of demand:
  • Adding-up: $$-1$$
  • Homogeneity or Cournot: $$-n$$
  • Symmetry: $$-(n^2-n)/2$$
Thus, with restrictions the number of parameters is reduced to $$(n^2-n)/2 -1 +n$$ Pogandy96:
The LES conforms to the four properties required for a consistent and complete demand system. The property of zero homogeneity in prices (the “absence of money illusion requirement)" follows from the formulation of the equations. Multiplication of each price term _by the same constant will leave the system unperturbed both in terms of level and allocation of expenditures. The adding-up property (i.e., expenditures on individual commodities add up to the budget constraint) and the property of symmetry (i.e., cross--partial price derivatives are equal) are algebraically imposed. The negativity property (i.e., the demand curves generated by the system are either downward sloping or horizontal) follows?om actual calculations. Compliance with the fourth property is fulfilled when the matrix of compensated cross-price elasticities (also called the substitution or Slutsky matrix) forms a negative semidefinite. The latter means that the own-price derivatives are non-positive, i.e., zero or negative. The terms of the substitution matrix may be expressed in elasticity terms. The algebraic manipulations that lead from the own- and cross- derivatives to the respective elasticities do not change the signs of the terms.

item.title: Theoretical regularity conditions for demand systems
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
• Cooper & McLaren (1992):
    • Engel aggregation: $$\sum_i w_i \eta_i = 1$$ (All additional income needs to be spend.)
    • Cournot aggregation: $$\sum_i w_i \epsilon_{ij} = -w_j \quad \forall j$$ (Reflects that total expenditure cannot change if only prices change.)
    • Homogeneity: $$\eta_i + \sum_j \epsilon_{ij} = 0 \quad \forall i$$
    • Symmetry: $$w_i(\epsilon_{ij} + w_j \eta_i) = w_j(\epsilon_{ji} + w_i \eta_j) \quad \forall i, j$$
    • Concavity: $$s_{ij} = w_i(\epsilon_{ij} + w_j \eta_i) \quad$$ $$S$$ must be a negative semi-definite matrix. A simple necessary condition is that all compensated own price elasticities must be negative.
  • Chang (2012): theoretical regularity conditions (of positivity, monotonicity, and curvature)

  • explaining regularity and discussing AIDS and more: Cooper (2006)

  • " global regularity, i.e., fully consistent with the maximization of utility subject to a budget constraint over the entire price-expenditure region" (mclaren14)

  • regularity of the LES: "Therefore, the regularity region is an unbounded region in price-expenditure space, potentially including all points in the sample, and all points corresponding to higher levels of “real income”. A well-known example of such a system is the Linear Expenditure system (LES), which is regular over an unbounded region but only for sufficiently high expenditure levels." (mclaren14)

  • caves80: "Flexible functional forms are attractive because they do not place any prior restrictions on consumer behavior at a base point. A precise statement of this flexibility property follows: For any particular data point (one observation on prices and income) any set of price and income elasticities can be achieved through an appropriate set of parameter values. A nonflexible form is only capable of achieving a subset of the full range of price and income elasticities."

  • caves80: 'We use "regularity conditions" as shorthand for monotonicity and strict quasi convexity of the indirect utility function. We use "regular region" as shorthand for "region in which the regularity conditions are satisfied." '

  • a functional form cannot be both globally regular and flexible (for n>2 items)

  • caves80:

    • direct utility function: monotonically increasing in quantities and strictly quasi concave
    • indirect utility function V: max. utility attainable given any set of prices p_i and income M; V is monotonically decreasing function of p_i / M (which can be checked by first order partial derivatives dV/dp_i <0 or equivalently budget shares w_i>0) and strictly quasi convex
  • Propterties of the indirect utility function
    • Monotonicity: utility increases whenever the consumption of one good increases while those of the others are at least not decreasing.
    • Convexity: "averages are better than extremes"
    • Monotonicity and convexity together guarantee that any solution to the consumer's first-order conditions solves the consumer's utility maximization problem.
  • economic theory of preferences, 5 axioms of consumer choice (see, e.g., Jehle, 2011 and Nechyba, 2011):
    1. Completeness: all choices of bundles can be compared
    2. Transitivity: if x>y and y>z then x>z
    3. Monotonicity: Consumer always prefers more of each good to less (=> indifference curves are downward sloping
    4. Convexity: indifference curves are convex, consumers prefer averages over extremes or variety over extremes (some of both goods rather than a lot of one good)
    5. Continuity: "no sudden jumps" or reversals in preference relations,

item.title: Imposing curvature / negativity / concavity on demand systems
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Imposing local regularity, that is, curvature or negativity on demand systems: On theoretical regularity of demand systems in general: barnett08 On imposing curvature:
  • ryan98
  • chang12, chang13
  • moro00
  • wolff10

Ryan & Wales (1998):

Local curvature at the reference point $$m=1, p_i=1 \quad \forall i$$ in an AIDS demand system without loss of flexibility can be imposed by adding constraints on the $$\gamma_{ij}$$ parameters:
$$\gamma_{ij} = -(KK') _{ij} + (\alpha_i - \beta_i \alpha_0) \delta _{ij} - (\alpha_j - \beta_j \alpha_0)(\alpha_i - \beta_i \alpha_0) + \beta_i \beta_j \alpha_0$$
with $$\delta _{ij}$$: =1 if i=j and =0 otherwise and K: a lower triangular matrix so that elements $$k$$ of $$K$$ are $$k _{ij}=0 \quad \forall j>i$$.
Element (i,j) of (KK'): $$(KK') _{ij} = \sum _{s \in I} k _{is} \cdot k _{js}$$ The reference point is taken as the average of the values. All prices and the income a normalized to 1 by scaling (adapting the units of measurement). In case of budget share equations, it is sufficient to set all goods' prices and the income to one. In case of quantity equations, prices and income are set to one and the quantities equal to the budget shares.

Chang & Serletis (2012):

Extended the Ryan & Wales (1998) approach to the QUAIDS:
$$\gamma_{ij} = -(KK')_{ij} + (-\alpha_0 \beta_i + \alpha_0^2 \lambda_i + \alpha_i)\delta _{ij} + \alpha_0\beta_i\beta_j \\- \alpha_0^2 \beta_i \lambda_j - \alpha_0^2 \beta_j \lambda_i + 2 \alpha_0^3\lambda_i\lambda_j - \alpha_i\alpha_j \\+ \alpha_0 \alpha_i \beta_j + \alpha_0 \alpha_j \beta_i - \alpha_0^2\alpha_i \lambda_j - \alpha_0^2\alpha_j\lambda_i \\- \alpha_0^2\beta_i\beta_j + \alpha_0^3\beta_i\lambda_j + \alpha_0^3\beta_j\lambda_i - \alpha_0^4\lambda_i\lambda_j$$

item.title: AIDS parameter calibration
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
From Sadoulet & de Janvry (1995), p.12:
$$\eta_i = 1 + \frac{\beta_i}{w_i}$$
Thus:
$$\beta_i = (\eta_i - 1)w_i$$ $$\epsilon_{ij} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{\gamma_{ij}}{w_i} - \frac{\beta_j}{w_i}w_j$$ Thus:
$$\gamma_{ij} = w_i(\epsilon_{ij} + \delta_{ij}) + w_j \beta_j$$ And finally, using the full AIDS budget share equation:
$$w_i = \alpha_i + \sum_j \gamma_{ij} \ln p_j + \beta_i \ln (\frac{m}{a(P)})$$
with
$$\ln a(P) = \alpha_0 + \sum_k \alpha_k \ln p_k + \frac{1}{2}\sum_j \sum_k \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \ln p_j$$
Thus:
$$\alpha_i = w_i - \sum_j \gamma_{ij} \ln p_j - \beta_i \ln (\frac{m}{a(P)})$$
But where how to get a(P) as it also includes alpha_i? Can one use some other price index for approximation?

item.title: Likelihood ratio test for nested models
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
• called: likelihood ratio (lr) test
  • To test whether a more general model fits statistically significantly better than the more restricted one (e.g. the QUAIDS better than the AIDS).
  • A nice explanation: http://www.ats.ucla.edu/stat/stata/faq/nested_tests.htm
  • Answers question, e.g.: Does constraining some parameters joint to zero (i.e., leaving out these predictor variables) significantly reduce the fit of the model?
  • Formula: $$LR = -2 \ln(\frac{Lik(model1)}{Lik(model2)} = 2(logLik(model2)- logLik(model1))$$ where Lik: likelihood and logLik: log likelihood of the respective model. This statistic is distributed chi-squared with degrees of freedom equal to the difference in the number of degrees of freedom between the two models (i.e., the number of variables added to the model).
  • also see: systemfit paper by henningsen07
  • using the lr test for a single added predictor is equivalent to the test of significance of the coefficient in the regression (see above web reference)
  • applied in abdulai04
  • explained in bopape06, p.87f.
  • also nice web page on likelihood ratio tests and other from PennState

Can the test be used to justify different models for disjoint subgroups of observations, e.g. urban vs. rural households?

  • mutuc07 perform two sample t-test to determine whether estimated elasticities differ between rural and urban households.
  • http://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/62179/is-this-a-nested-model-and-can-i-use-the-likelihood-ratio-test
  • check statement read Mafuru 2003 (paper not saved): "To test rural and urban data relative to the pooled data, likelihood ratio tests were conducted using the statistic LR = 2(LL(P) -LL(R+U) ). Here LL(P) is the log likelihood value from the pooled sample regression and LL(R+U) a total of maximized likelihood values in rural and urban samples."
  • See: http://www.theanalysisfactor.com/compare-regression-coefficients/
    A nested model for two subsamples (groups) can be created by using a group dummy in interaction with all of the predictors. The coefficients of those new interacted predictors is then the difference between group 1 and group 2 (and the significance indicates significant difference!).

This last problem is exacerbated by the otherwise desirable use of flexible functional forms."
    • p171: "Grouping goods into broad aggregates is generally rationalized by assuming preferences are separable. Many forms of separability exist, each implying somewhat different restrictions on preferences. See, for example, Deaton and Muellbauer (1980a), Pollak and Wales (1992), Blackorby, Primont, and Russell (1978) and the references contained therein. In practice, the form of separability that is most often assumed (either implicitly or explicitly) is weak homo the tic separability, since this rationalizes the standard practice of constructing a price index for each good and defining quantities as total expenditures on each good divided by each good's price index, and it implies that direct utility, indirect utility, and cost functions written in terms of these quantity and price indices possess all the same properties as the corresponding functions of individual goods."

item.title: Causes of zero expenditure levels
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Consistent Estimation of Longitudinal Censored Demand Systems - An Application to Transition Country Data (meyerhoefer03):
There are several reasons why zero expenditure levels manifest in microeconomic data, the two most common of which are households at a corner solution for the commodity in question and limited survey periods leading to infrequency of purchase (IFP) errors. The former occurs when the market price for a good is equal to or greater than the consumer’s reservation price, while the latter results from the high cost of extending survey periods to the point where purchases of all goods and services are observed. More recent surveys have attempted to minimize IFP errors by extending data collection periods beyond the two-week norm and using multiple-year recall to enumerate infrequently purchased durable goods. Because of the basis for corner solutions in economic theory, most of the econometric techniques developed thus far are designed to capture economic non-consumption.

item.title: Weak separability in demand system analysis
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
(Edgerton et al. 1996, p.69) This approach implies that goods can be divided into a number of "separate" groups, where a change of price in a good in one group affects the demand for all goods in another group in the same manner.
(Edgerton et al. 1996) Briefly, weak separability of consumer demand can be explained as follows; the marginal rate of substitution for two commodities in the same group is not affected by the consumption of a commodity in a different group.
(Pollak and Wales, 1992) ...implies that the demand for a good in a particular subset (e.g., Swiss cheese in the food subset) can be expressed as a function of the prices of the goods in that subset and total expenditure on those goods (food prices and total expenditure on food). Although it would be more convenient if the demand for Swiss cheese depended only on food prices and total expenditure (jit), this is not what separability implies. Instead, separability implies that expenditure and the prices of goods outside the food subset enter the demand functions for food only through their effect on total expenditure on food. Thus, if we work with expenditure on food rather than total expenditure on all goods, we can ignore the prices of goods outside the food category.

item.title: Handling the "other" consumption items (like "other meat") in deriving prices
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The Uganda NHS 2005/06 contains several items "other": other fruits, other meat, other vegetables, other alcoholic drinks, other juice, other foods. The prices derived for those "other" items vary hugely likely because the actual items behind this might be very different. Three ad hoc approaches to deal with such items come to mind:
  1. Select all closely related items, e.g. in the case of "other meat" those are beef, goat, pork, chicken and impute the average price of those.
  2. Select a very closely related item and impute its price.
  3. Assume no knowledge about the price of the "other" item is available and impute a price of one. Thus, this item then has no price variation and can only be explained via expenditure level.
Different "other" items can justify different approaches. Approach for UNHS 05/06:
  • "other meat": use non-weighted average price (not only coefficient but the estimated price) of {beef, pork, goat meat, chicken}
  • "other fruits": avg. price of {Passion Fruits, Sweet bananas, Mangoes, Oranges}
  • "other vegetables": avg. price of {Onions, Tomatoes, Cabbages, Dodo}
  • "other drinks": use price of Soda
  • "other alcoholic drinks": use price of beer
  • "other juice": use price of Soda
  • "other foods": use price of 1

item.title: Estimating the indirect addilog (IAS) demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The goal is to first estimate an IAS to produce a feasible solution from where to start the estimation of the CDE. The IAS solution can also be used as priors on the CDE parameters. Below are some equations and references and the estimation procedure has been started in GCE__est_master.gms . The procedure is incomplete as of now. What needs to be done next is:
  • look at literature for sensible bounds on the parameters and priors
  • reduce # of equations, e.g. IAS(I,I2) only where I<I2, possibly only one equation per item (against which?)
  • currently, only non-zero expenditures are accounted for in estimation => add standard log equation (not divided / subtracted between two items). This will be hard to estimate but is there an alternative?
Literature showing IAS estimation equations:
  • Houthakker 1960 (primary source)
  • Somermeyer 1972 (primary source)
  • Taylor 2004
  • de Boer 2009
  • Conniffe 2003
  • Suharno 2010
Budget share equation: $$ w_i = \frac{\alpha_i (\frac{p_i}{M})^{\beta_i}\exp(u_i)}{\sum_j \alpha_j (\frac{p_j}{M})^{\beta_j}\exp(u_j)} = \frac{\alpha_i p_i^{\beta_i}M^{-\beta_i}}{\sum_j \alpha_j p_j^{\beta_j}M^{-\beta_j}} $$ In reference to CDE: IAS assumes $$\tau_i \beta_i = g \quad \forall i$$ $$\Rightarrow \alpha_i = \psi_i \beta_i \Leftrightarrow \psi = \frac{\alpha_i}{\beta_i}$$ Question: Can we set all $$\tau_i = 1$$ to get an initial feasible solution for the CDE? IAS estimation equation a la Houthakker (1960): $$\ln w_i - ln w_j = \ln \alpha_i - \ln \alpha_j + \beta_i \ln \frac{p_i}{M} - \beta_j \ln \frac{p_j}{M} + u_i - u_j $$

item.title: AIDS expenditure function / cost function
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
The expenditure function underlying the AIDS (see Decoster & Vermeulen, 1998) is $latex \ln C_{\mathrm{AIDS}} (u,p) = \ln a(p) + u b(p) \label{eq:AIDS_C}$ The expenditure required to attain the utility level of period zero assuming the prices of period one $latex C(u^0,p^1)$ can be derived by solving the expenditure function $latex C(u^0,p^0) = M$ for $latex u$ and substituting this together with $latex a(p^1)$ and $latex b(p^1)$ into equation \eqref{eq:AIDS_C}. Compensated income: $latex \ln C(u,p') = \ln a(p') + (ln M - \ln a(p)) \frac{b(p')}{b(p)}$
Equivalent income: $latex \ln C(u',p) = \ln a(p) + (\ln M' - \ln a(p')) \frac{b(p)}{b(p')}$

Treating endogeneity of total expenditures:
  • In a demand system under separability, it is usual to allow for the endogeneity of total expenditure. There are several reasons why total expenditure might be endogenous in a demand system. It could be that total expenditure is correlated with taste shocks that also affect budget shares. For instance, a shock that increases food spending increases both the budget share of food as well as total expenditure. Another reason for endogeneity is measurement error in total expenditure. To instrument for this, we follow the literature (Banks, Blundell, and Lewbel, 1997) by using after tax income as an instrument for total expenditure.
