item.title: Deriving censored QUAIDS elasticities accounting for marginal effects of probit
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Censored QUAIDS formulas (Shonkwiler & Yen): $latex w^*_i = \Phi_i \cdot w_i + \theta_i \phi_i$
where $latex w^*_i$ is the latent, non-censored budget share equation and $latex w_i$ the censored budget shares (as in the original QUAIDS equation which does not account for censoring) .
To account for the marginal effect due to a variable (e.g., income) occurring in both the probit ($latex d^*_i$) and QUAIDS equations, the $latex \Phi_i(d^*_i(m,p,z))$ and $latex \phi_i(d^*_i(m,p,z))$ functions have to be treated as depending on that variable.
$latex w^*_i = \Phi_i \left[ \alpha_i + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k + \beta_i \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) + \frac{\lambda_i}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right] + \theta_i \phi_i$ with $latex \ln a(p) = \alpha_0 + \sum_{k \in I} \alpha_k \ln p_k + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{k \in I} \sum_{l \in I} \gamma_{kl} \ln p_k \ln p_l $
$latex b(p) = \prod_{k \in I} p_k^{\beta_k} $
$latex q_i = \frac{m}{p_i} w^*_i $
$latex q_i = \frac{m}{p_i} \left[ \Phi_i w_i + \phi_i \right] $
$latex \frac{\partial \ln a(p)}{\partial p_j} = \frac{\alpha_j}{p_j} + \frac{1}{p_j} \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k$     (depends on symmetry of gamma!)
$latex \frac{\partial b(p)}{\partial p_j} = \beta_j p_j^{-1} \prod_{k \in I} p_k^{\beta_k} = \frac{\beta_j}{p_j} b(p) $
$latex \frac{\partial \phi_i}{\partial m} = -\frac{\tau_{i,\ln(m)}}{m} d^*_i \phi_i$
$latex \frac{\partial \Phi_i}{\partial m} = \frac{\tau_{i,\ln(m)}}{m} \phi_i$
$latex q_i = \frac{m}{p_i} \left[ \Phi_i \left[ \alpha_i + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{ik} \ln p_k + \beta_i \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) + \frac{\lambda_i}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right] + \theta_i \phi_i \right] $
Derive expenditure elasticity: $latex \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial m} = \frac{1}{p_i} w_i + \frac{m}{p_i} \frac{\partial w^*_i}{\partial m}$
$latex \frac{\partial w^*_i}{\partial m} = \phi_i \frac{\tau_{i,\ln(m)}}{m} w_i + \Phi_i \frac{\partial w_i}{\partial m} - \theta_i \phi_i d^*_i \frac{\tau_{i,\ln(m)}}{m}$
$latex \frac{\partial w_i}{\partial m} = \frac{\beta_i}{m} + \frac{2\lambda_i}{b(p)}\ln(\frac{m}{a(p)})\frac{1}{m}$
$latex \eta_i = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial m} \frac{m}{q_i} = 1 + \frac{m}{w^*_i} \frac{\partial w^*_i}{\partial m}$
$latex \boxed{\eta_i = 1 + \frac{1}{w^*_i} \left[ \Phi_i \left( \beta_i + \frac{2\lambda_i}{b(p)}\ln(\frac{m}{a(p)}) \right) + \tau_{i,\ln(m)} \phi_i (w_i - \theta_i d^*_i ) \right] }$
Derive uncompensated price elasticity:
$latex \varepsilon_{ij} = \frac{\partial q_i}{\partial p_j} \frac{p_j}{q_i} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{p_j}{w^*_i} \frac{\partial w^*_i}{\partial p_j}$
$latex \frac{\partial w^*_i}{\partial p_j} = \phi_i \frac{\tau_{i,\ln(p_j)}}{p_j} w_i + \Phi_i \frac{\partial w_i}{\partial p_j} - \theta_i \phi_i d^*_i \frac{\tau_{i,\ln(p_j)}}{p_j}$
$latex \frac{\partial w_i}{\partial p_j} = \frac{1}{p_j} \left[ \gamma_{ij} - \left( \beta_i + \frac{2 \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right) \left( \alpha_j + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \right) - \frac{\lambda_i \beta_j}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left(\frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right]$
$latex \boxed{\varepsilon_{ij} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{1}{w^*_i} \left[ \tau_{i,\ln(p_j)} \phi_i (w_i - \theta_i d^*_i ) + \Phi_i \left[ \gamma_{ij} - \left( \beta_i + \frac{2 \lambda_i}{b(p)} \ln \left( \frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right) \left( \alpha_j + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k \right) - \frac{\lambda_i \beta_j}{b(p)} \left( \ln \left(\frac{m}{a(p)} \right) \right)^2 \right] \right]} $
with
Kronecker Delta   $latex \delta_{ij}=1$   if   $latex i=j$   and   $latex =0$   otherwise. Recall again that $latex w_i$ denotes the non-censored QUAIDS budget share equation while $latex w^*_i$ denotes the censored QUAIDS budget share equation.

item.title: Demand system estimations: relevance for food security and policy implications
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Phrases

  • progress towards MDGs
  • made much headway in reducing poverty
  • strong economic growth, avg. annual GDP growth of %
  • favorable future outlook as start of oil exploitation
  • however:
  • number of people undernourished not reduced
  • many people poor
  • many people in permanent or transitory food insecurity
  • with growth, economic development as well as increasing regional and international integration, the economic environment as well as policy will change needing to ensure that the progress accomplished in reducing poverty and malnutrition and increasing food security is not endangered but instead advanced further. This might call for policy which in turn needs evidence-based assessments of the economic and policy changes such that policy makers have a quantitative information enabling to identify the most efficient policies to achieve and secure the development targets under fiscal budget constraints. One aspect of this is demand side analysis.
  • not to jeopardize advances made
  • positive outlook for Uganda's future
  • demand side questions:
  • who needs cushioning from upcoming economic events
  • how will demand patterns changes?
  • As a basis for discussion, we adopt the food security definition from ... which sets x dimensions
  • Targeting and efficiency of programs to increase food security need detailed information on how food consumption patterns change in reaction to external events, altering economic circumstances and to food security policies.
  • Efficiency of FS programs: To increase the food security of households at risk to a certain level with a minimum of financial resources.
  • Needs to avoid leakages of support to
    • food-secure households
    • consumption which does not increase households' food security
  • Policy options to increase food security on the demand side:
    • any policies which reduce consumer prices
    • direct cash / income transfers
    • in-kind transfers / directly provide food
    • food stamp programs
    • consumer price subsidies
    • nutrition-oriented consumer education (barrett02: 43)
  • Particular policy options might not be viable at every time and for every location / country which possibly necessitates adoption of a less efficient alternative + administrative cost / fiscal budget constraints or donor constraints
  • Policies can cause both at the same time displacement and substitution by food provided
  • Counteracting impacts on production side?
  • Other problems which cannot be dealt with by demand system: micronutrient deficiencies (e.g. fortification program such as iodized salt)
  • Targeting: "self-targeting through subsidies to inferior foods and food-for-work schemes" (barrett02). + inferior grade foods
  • subsidized inferior foods could be turned into high quality animal feed thereby indirectly subsidizing rich meat consumers

    • Quotes

    • Bullock08:
      • efficiency with which ag policy instruments transfers income among interest groups
      • theoretical review and exposition of the effects of elasticities on redistribution efficiency
    • Barrett02:
      • food assistance programs: basic aim is to reduce food insecurity, i.e., to avert rather than to reverse nutritional problems.
      Food security reflects not only ensured access to sufficient quantities and quality of food, but also secure access to complementary inputs (e.g., education, health, sanitation, water) that affect the efficiency of conversion of consumed food into physical well-being. One important implication of the relatively modest income elasticity of food is that price policies may be more effective than income policies in stimulating additional food demand, if indeed that is an objective. While food subsidy schemes substantially predated the emergence of this ?nding in the literature, it has been seized upon in recent years as a justi?cation for targeted subsidy schemes, particularly on inferior foods or grades of foods (see Section 3.3.2). However, using price policy to try to enhance the food security runs the risk of either (a) creating signi?cant production disincentives that may ultimately hurt vulnerable subpopulations more than subsidies help them (see the discussion of disincentives, below), or (b) pursuing ?scally unsustainable state subsidies, a common outcome of generalized subsidies for staple foods [Pinstrup- Andersen (1988)]. Moreover, food subsidies tend to bene?t urban populations more than rural ones [Lipton (1977), Alderman (1991)]. p.63: There, self-targeting FAPs may be especially useful. The two most common forms of self-targeting FAPs are subsidies on inferior foods and food-for-work schemes. Subsidies applied to inferior foods and grades of foods – on which expenditures decline as total expenditures increase – can be effectively targeted. Foods most in demand by the poor as a low-cost source of nutrients offering few other redeeming attributes can endogenously direct assistance toward those most needing it without the need for complementary ICAT. In other words, subsidize foods that exhibit high income and (negative) price elasticities of demand among the poor but low income and price elasticities of demand among the rich.
    • UN, The United Nations University Press Food and Nutrition Bulletin Volume 6, Number 1, March 1984 (http://archive.unu.edu/unupress/food/8F061e/8F061E01.htm), Ch1:
      The second way out of the dilemma is to take advantage of the fact that the low average price and income elasticities of demand are the result of almost unitary elasticities for the very poor and very low elasticities for the rich. (Unitary elasticities mean that a 1 per cent increase in income, or a 1 per cent decrease in price, generates a 1 per cent increase in consumption.) This statistical fact is quite logical. A poor family will spend most of any additional income on food, and decreases in food prices will increase its food purchases substantially. In the case of rich households, changes in income or food prices affect food consumption very little. A developing country that wants to promote food production and at the same time increase the income of poor farmers can increase food demand by transferring food purchasing power to the poor, and thus avoid the negative nutrition and incentive effects of lower farm prices on poor rural families. Because small farmers produce in part for their own consumption, giving them capability for greater production will increase both the supply and demand for food, because one expects these families to have high demand elasticities for food. But any increase in marketed food production must be matched with purchasing power transfers to landless farmers and the urban poor in order to increase food demand and thereby avoid a substantial fall in farm prices. These income transfers are hard to set up and administer. Targeting food subsidies or income transfers to landless rural workers is particularly difficult, but even in the urban areas food subsidies or food coupons often benefit the well-off more than the poor. Designing effective and efficient delivery systems is a real challenge both conceptually and administratively. Few countries can show successful subsidy systems. This is an area where policy analysis can make a real contribution to human welfare. Realistically, the food subsidy or income transfer schemes must be quite well targeted in order to keep government expenditures on this component of development strategy at a reasonable level. Most counries today have a serious fiscal problem, and it is unreasonable to expect them to maintain massive government expenditures on food subsidies or income transfers for a long time in order to improve the nutritional status of their populations.

item.title: Injecting MAFAP data into the Uganda SAM
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Goal: replicate the price gap between border price $$P_B$$ and farmgate price $$P_F$$ as given by MAFAP data, attributing the gap to border taxes and access costs. Exports:
  1. From MAFAP data: The export tax rate is equal to the price gap $$PG = P_B - P_F$$ minus the part explained by access costs (both, from the border to wholesale and from wholesale to farmgate) $$AC$$ divided by $$P_B$$: $$\tau_e = \dfrac{PG - AC}{P_B}$$
  2. Calculate the access costs as a share of the tax value: $$ACETAXSHR = \dfrac{AC}{P_{etax}}$$ where $$P_{etax} = PG - AC$$.
  3. In the SAM, calculate the value of the exported goods at the farmgate: $$V_F = V_B - ETAX - TRCE = V_B - \tau_e V_B - ACETAXSHR \tau_e V_B$$. Thus, the value at the border is $$SAM_{c,row} = V_B = \dfrac{V_F}{1 - \tau_e - ACETAXSHR \tau_e}$$.
  4. Calculate the value of the export tax $$SAM_{etax,c} = \tau_e \cdot SAM_{c,row}$$.
  5. Calculate the value of the export transaction costs $$SAM_{trce,c} = ACETAXSHR * SAM_{etax,c}$$.
Imports:
  1. Calculate import tariff $$\tau_m = -\tau_e$$.
  2. Calculate the access costs as a share of the tax value: $$ACMTAXSHR = \dfrac{AC}{P_{mtax}}$$ where $$P_{mtax} = PG- AC$$.
  3. Split ACMTAXSHR into access costs from farmgate to wholesale and from border to wholesale:
    • $$ACMTAXSHR_B = \frac{AC_B}{AC} * ACMTAXSHR$$
    • $$ACMTAXSHR_F = \frac{AC_F}{AC} * ACMTAXSHR$$
  4. In the SAM, calculate the import tariff value $$SAM_{mtax,c} = \tau_m \cdot SAM_{row,c}$$.
  5. Calculate the value of the import transaction costs $$SAM_{trcm,c} = ACMTAXSHR_B * SAM_{mtax,c}$$.
  6. Calculate the value of the domestic to wholesale market transaction costs $$SAM_{trcd,c} = ACMTAXSHR_F * SAM_{mtax,c}$$.

item.title: Uganda NRA problems
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Current problems:
  1. Wheat price in 2008 decreases compared to 2006 if deflated. That is because the nominal wheat price stated by MAFAP remains constant. Potential solutions:
    • Use non-food price index as deflator instead of CPI. But the resulting wheat price would still be decreasing.
    • Only use the derived access cost and policy wedge and apply to world market price to derive domestic price change.
  2. The cause of the domestic price change, which cannot be explained by the change in the international price and in the imperfect price transmission (access cost and policy wedge change) is very important as it rather directly affects household incomes. A supply (TFP) shock has strong negative implications while a demand shock (e.g., informal cross-border trade) has strong positive implications. What does the literature state about the causes?

item.title: Leontief demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
See wilcoxen03 and pollack,wales,1992:26
Utility function: $$u = \min_{i} \dfrac{q_i}{\alpha_i}$$
with $$\alpha_i > 0$$.
The utility function cannot be differentiated and thus the Lagrange maximization approach does not work. But it is easy to see, that for a utility maximizing consumption bundle, all $$q_i/\alpha_i$$ ratios need to be equal.
Indirect utility function: $$v = m \left(\sum_i \alpha_i p_i\right)^{-1}$$
Expenditure function: $$E(p,u)=u \sum_i \alpha_i p_i$$
Demand function: $$q_i = \alpha_i \dfrac{m}{\sum_j \alpha_j p_j}$$
Demand function in expenditure share form: $$w_i = \alpha_i \dfrac{p_i}{\sum_j \alpha_j p_j}$$
Income elasticity: $$\eta_i = 1$$
Own-price elasticity: $$\varepsilon_{ii} = -w_i$$
Cross-price elasticity: $$\varepsilon_{ij} = -w_j$$

item.title: Cobb-Douglas Demand System
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Utility function: $$u=\prod_i q_i^{\alpha_i}$$
Indirect utility: $$v=m \prod_i (\frac{\alpha_i}{p_i})^{\alpha_i}$$
Expenditure function: $$E=u \prod_i (\frac{p_i}{\alpha_i})^{\alpha_i}$$

item.title: Cost functions of the AIDS and QUAIDS
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
See banks97 and decoster98

AIDS

Indirect utility function: $$\ln V = \frac{\ln m - \ln a(p)}{b(p)}$$ with $$\ln a(p) = \alpha_o + \sum_k \alpha_k \ln p_k + \frac{1}{2} \sum_k \sum_j \gamma_kj \ln p_k \ln p_j$$ $$b(p) = \prod_i p_i^{\beta_i}$$ Expenditure function: $$\ln E(u,p) = \ln a(p) + \ln V \cdot b(p)$$ Checking the negativity / curvature property for the AIDS: see Deaton & Muellbauer (1980: 316).

QUAIDS

Indirect utility function: $$\ln V = \left[ \left( \frac{\ln m - \ln a(p)}{b(p)} \right)^{-1} + \sum_i \lambda_i \ln p_i \right]^{-1}$$ with $$\ln a(p) = \alpha_o + \sum_k \alpha_k \ln p_k + \frac{1}{2} \sum_k \sum_j \gamma_kj \ln p_k \ln p_j$$ $$b(p) = \prod_i p_i^{\beta_i}$$ Expenditure function: $$\ln E(u,p) = \ln a(p) + \frac{\ln V \cdot b(p)}{1 - \ln V \sum_i \lambda_i \ln p_i}$$ Checking the negativity / curvature property for the QUAIDS: see Decoster & Vermeulen (1998: 7).

item.title: Perfect substitutes demand system
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
See deaton98 and "indirect utility and expenditure function - some examples.pdf" Perfect substitutes have linear indifference curves and the MRS is constant, independently of the levels of consumption of the various items.
Utility: $$U = \sum_i \alpha_i q_i$$ Demand: $$q_i = \frac{M}{p_i} \; \text{ if } \; \frac{p_i}{p_j} < \frac{\alpha_i}{\alpha_j} \quad \forall j$$ and $$q_i = 0$$ otherwise. If $$p_i \alpha_j = p_j \alpha_i$$ then the individual is indifferent between all combinations of the goods. Indirect utility: $$V(p,M) = \max_i {\frac{\alpha_i M}{p_i} }$$ Expenditure function: $$E(p,U) = \min_i {\frac{p_i U}{\alpha_i} }$$

item.title: Negative semi-definite matrix ; minors
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
Let A be an n×n symmetric matrix. Then, A is a positive semidefinite iff every principal minor of A is ≥0; A is a negative semidefinite iff every principal minor of odd order is ≤0 and every principal minor of even order is ≥0.
  • A matrix is negative semi-definite iff every principal minor of odd order is <=0 and every principal minor of even order is >=0
  • Minor: If A is a square matrix, then the minor of the entry in the i-th row and j-th column (also called the (i,j) minor, or a first minor[1]) is the determinant of the submatrix formed by deleting the i-th row and j-th column. This number is often denoted M_{i,j}.
  • Principal minor: The kth order principal minors of an n × n symmetric matrix A are the determinants of the k × k matrices obtained by deleting n - k rows and the corresponding n - k columns of A (where k = 1, ..., n)

item.title: Demand system GCE: concavity / curvature of QUAIDS
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
During the calibration of the QUAIDS model, concavity of the cost function (the negativity property of demand functions) is enforced locally at the point of calibration by a constraint based on Chang and Serletis (2012). Since this crucially relies on income and prices having been normalized to equal one and this cannot be held up for additional income points, another approach is added to improve the curvature properties at those points. More specifically, a necessary and sufficient condition for concavity is the semi-definiteness of the Slutsky matrix or the matrix of compensated price responses.
For additional income points, complementary constraints enforce some necessary conditions for semi-definiteness of the Slutsky matrix of compensated price effects(Deaton & Muellbauer 1980). More specifically, a matrix is negative semi-definite, if and only if all principal minors of odd order are non-positive and those of even order are non-negative. However, this is not easily tested for large matrices because of the number of variables and equations it requires. Therefore, we only enforce these inequalities for the principal minors of orders one to four, denoted by $latex \varepsilon^c_{ii}$, $latex M^2_{ij}$, $latex M^3_{ijk}$ and $latex M^4_{ijkl}$, respectively.
$latex \begin{aligned} M^2_{ij} &= \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_i} \cdot \frac{\partial q^c_j}{\partial p_j} - \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_j} \cdot \frac{\partial q^c_j}{\partial p_i}\\ M^3_{ijk} &= \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_i} \cdot M^2_{jk} - \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_j} \cdot M^2_{ik} + \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_k} \cdot M^2_{ij}\\ M^4_{ijkl} &= \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_i} \cdot M^3_{jkl} - \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_j} \cdot M^3_{ikl} + \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_k} \cdot M^3_{ijl} - \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_l} \cdot M^3_{ijk}\\ \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_i} &\le 0 &\forall i \in I\\ M^2_{ij} &\ge 0 &\forall i,j \in \{I|j>i\}\\ M^3_{ijk} &\le 0 &\forall i,j,k \in \{I|k>j>i\}\\ M^4_{ijkl} &\ge 0 &\forall i,j,k,l \in \{I|l>k>j>i\} \end{aligned} $
Since multiplying $latex \frac{\partial q^c_i}{\partial p_j}$ by a positive number $latex \frac{p_j}{q_i}$ will not change the sign of the term, the constraints can also be formulated using the compensated cross-price elasticities.
$latex \begin{aligned} M^2_{ij} &= \varepsilon^c_{ii} \cdot \varepsilon^c_{jj} - \varepsilon^c_{ij} \cdot \varepsilon^c_{ji}\\ M^3_{ijk} &= \varepsilon^c_{ii} \cdot M^2_{jk} - \varepsilon^c_{ij} \cdot M^2_{ik} + \varepsilon^c_{ik} \cdot M^2_{ij}\\ M^4_{ijkl} &= \varepsilon^c_{ii} \cdot M^3_{jkl} - \varepsilon^c_{ij} \cdot M^3_{ikl} + \varepsilon^c_{ik} \cdot M^3_{ijl} - \varepsilon^c_{il} \cdot M^3_{ijk}\\ \varepsilon^c_{ii} &\le 0 &\forall i \in I\\ M^2_{ij} &\ge 0 &\forall i,j \in \{I|j>i\}\\ M^3_{ijk} &\le 0 &\forall i,j,k \in \{I|k>j>i\}\\ M^4_{ijkl} &\ge 0 &\forall i,j,k,l \in \{I|l>k>j>i\} \end{aligned} $

item.title: An implicit, directly additive demand system (AIDADS)
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
• Due to Rimmer and Powell (1996)
  • Effectively globally regular, rank 3
  • nests the LES (alpha_i = beta_i for all i)
  • Notation from Cranfield et al. (2002) (Yu et al. 2003)
  • See preckel10 for additional parameter restrictions
Budget shares: $$ w_i = \phi_i + \frac{p_i \gamma_i - \phi_i \sum_{j \in I} p_j \gamma_j}{m} $$ with $$ \phi_i = \frac{\alpha_i + \beta_i e^u}{1+e^u}$$ or quantity demanded: $$q_i = \gamma_i + \frac{\phi_i}{p_i} (M - \sum_{j \in I} p_j \gamma_j)$$ Implicit utility function: $$ 1 \equiv \sum_{i \in I} \phi_i \ln\left(\dfrac{q_i - \gamma_i}{A e^u} \right) $$ with restrictions: $$ 0 \le \alpha_i \le 1$$ $$ 0 \le \beta_i \le 1$$ $$ \sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i = 1$$ $$ \sum_{i \in I} \beta_i = 1$$ $$ 0 \le \gamma_i \le q_i$$ Implicit utility function, fully spelled out: $$ 1 \equiv \sum_{i \in I} \frac{\alpha_i + \beta_i e^u}{1+e^u} \ln\left(\dfrac{\gamma_i + \frac{\frac{\alpha_i + \beta_i e^u}{1+e^u}}{p_i} (M - \sum_{j \in I} p_j \gamma_j) - \gamma_i}{A e^u} \right) $$ Income elasticity: $$ \eta_i = \dfrac{\phi_i - (\beta_i - \alpha_i) \Upsilon }{w_i}$$ with $$ \Upsilon = \left( \sum_{i \in I} (\beta_i - \alpha_i) \ln (q_i - \gamma_i) - \dfrac{ (1 + e^u)^2}{e^u} \right)^{-1}$$ Regularity over some price-income space is only guaranteed if $$ \Upsilon < 0$$ Partial elasticity of substitution: $$ \sigma_{ij} = \dfrac{(q_i - \gamma_i)(q_j - \gamma_j)(m-\sum_{j \in I} p_j \gamma_j)}{q_i q_j m} \forall i,j \in {I|j \ne i}$$ Uncompensated price elasticity: $$ \varepsilon_{ij} = w_j(\sigma_{ij} - \eta_i)$$ Compensated price elasticity: $$ \varepsilon^c_{ij} = \sigma_{ij} w_j$$

item.title: Constant Elasticity of Substitution (CES) Demand System
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
• Homothetic utility function
Utility: $$u = \left(\sum_{\forall i \in I} \alpha_i q_i^{\frac{\sigma-1}{\sigma}}\right)^\frac{\sigma}{\sigma-1}$$ where $$\alpha_i$$ share parameters with $$0 < \alpha_i < 1$$ and $$\sum_{\forall i \in I} \alpha_i=1$$ and $$\sigma$$ the (constant) elasticity of substitution. (see, e.g., T. Nechyba, 2011, p. 126) Utility max. $$u$$ subject to $$\sum_{\forall i \in I} p_i q_i \le M$$. (Lagrange, FOCs => demand function) Demand function $$q_i = M \frac{\alpha_i^\sigma p_i^{-\sigma}}{\sum_{\forall j \in I} \alpha_j^{\sigma} p_j^{1-\sigma}}$$ Demand function in budget share form: $$w_i = \frac{\alpha_i^\sigma p_i^{1-\sigma}}{\sum_{\forall j \in I} \alpha_j^{\sigma} p_j^{1-\sigma}}$$ Income elasticity: $$\eta_i = 1$$ Own-price elasticity: $$\varepsilon_{ii} = -\sigma + (\sigma - 1) w_i$$ Cross-price elasticity: $$\varepsilon_{ij} = (\sigma -1)w_j$$ Thus, if $$\sigma > 1 \Rightarrow \varepsilon_{ij} > 0$$ and i and j are gross substitutes, if $$\sigma < 1 \Rightarrow \varepsilon_{ij} < 0$$ and i and j are gross complements. The CES only allows for normal goods and Engel curves are linear through the origin. Indirect utilitiy function (derived by plugging the quantity demand functions into the utility function and some tedious transformations): $$V(p,M) = \dfrac{M}{\left(\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i^\sigma p_i^{1-\sigma}\right)^\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}$$ Cost function or expenditure function: $$C(u, p) = V \cdot \left(\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i^\sigma p_i^{1-\sigma}\right)^\frac{1}{1-\sigma}$$ Equivalent income: $$C(u',p) = M'\dfrac{\left(\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i^\sigma p_i^{1-\sigma}\right)^\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}{\left(\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i^\sigma (p_i')^{1-\sigma}\right)^\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}$$ Compensated income: $$C(u,p') = M\dfrac{\left(\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i^\sigma (p_i')^{1-\sigma}\right)^\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}{\left(\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i^\sigma p_i^{1-\sigma}\right)^\frac{1}{1-\sigma}}$$ Limits for $$\sigma$$ (see Besanko & Bräutigam, 2011): $$0 \le \sigma \le \infty$$ and $$\sigma \neq 0$$ and $$\sigma \neq 1$$.
  • If $$\sigma = \infty$$ then indifference curves are straight lines and items are perfect substitutes.
  • If $$\sigma = 0$$ then indifference curves are L-shaped and items are perfect complements (fixed proportions).
  • If $$\sigma = 1$$ then indifference curves are curves and the function is Cobb-Douglas.
Literature: Chiang & Wainwright

item.title: Checking demand system for regularity
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
See barnett08, caves80. Serletis and Shahmoradi (2005), p. 10: The regularity conditions are checked as follows:
  • Positivity is checked by direct computation of the values of the estimated budget shares, $$\hat{s}_t$$. It is satisﬁed if $$\hat{s}_t \ge 0$$, for all t.
  • Monotonicity is checked by choosing a normalization on the indirect utility function so as to make $$h(p, m)$$ decreasing in its arguments and by direct computation of the values of the ﬁrst gradient vector of the estimated indirect utility function. It is satisfied if $$\hat{h}_p(p, m) < 0$$ and $$\hat{h}_m(p, m) > 0$$ or, equivalently, if $$\nabla\hat{h}(v) < 0$$, where $$\nabla\hat{h}(v) = (\partial/\partial v)\hat{h}(v)$$.
  • Curvature requires that the Slutsky matrix be negative semidefinite and is checked by performing a Cholesky factorization of that matrix and checking whether the Cholesky values are nonpositive [since a matrix is negative semidefinite if its Cholesky factors are nonpositive -- see Lau (1978, Theorem 3.2)]. Curvature can also be checked by examining the Allen elasticities of substitution matrix, provided that the monotonicity condition holds. It requires that this matrix be negative semidefinite.

item.title: MAIDS (modified AIDS)
item.dc:creator: Ole
item.content:encoded:
AIDS with improved regularity properties due to cooper92, mclaren95. MAIDS formulation mainly taken from mclaren95: $$u(M,p) = \ln(\frac{M}{a(p)}) \frac{M^\Omega}{\prod_{i \in I} p_i^{\beta_i}}$$ $$\ln a(p) = \alpha_0 + \sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i \ln p_i + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i \in I} \sum_{j \in I} \gamma_{ij} \ln p_i \ln p_j$$ $$\sum_{i \in I} \alpha_i = 1, \sum_{i \in I} \beta_i = \Omega, \sum_{j \in I} \gamma_{ij}=0 \forall i \in I$$ $$ \gamma_{ij} = \gamma_{ji} \forall i,j \in I$$ $$ \beta_i \ge 0 \forall i \in I$$ If $$0 \le \Omega \le 1$$ then the utility function satisfies monotonicity and curvature properties where $$\frac{M}{a(p)} \ge 1$$. $$w_i = \dfrac{\alpha_i + \sum_{j \in I} \gamma_{ij} \ln p_j + \beta_i \ln(\frac{M}{a(p)})}{1 + \Omega \ln(\frac{M}{a(p)})}$$ Cost function (no explicit analytical representation possible, see cooper92: 657): $$\ln C(u,p) = \ln a(p) + \dfrac{u \prod_{i \in I} p_i^{\beta_i}}{[C(u,p)]^{\Omega}}$$ The MAIDS becomes AIDS for $$\Omega = 0$$ and $$\beta_i$$ unbounded. Elasticities (expanded from cooper92: 659) Expenditure elasticity: $$\eta_i = 1 + \dfrac{\beta_i - \Omega w_i}{w_i (1+\Omega \ln(\frac{M}{a(p)}))}$$ Price elasticity: $$\varepsilon_{ij} = -\delta_{ij} + \frac{1}{1 + \Omega \ln(\frac{M}{a(p)})} \left[\frac{\gamma_{ij}}{w_i} + (\Omega - \frac{\beta_i}{w_i})\cdot (\alpha_j + \sum_{k \in I} \gamma_{jk} \ln p_k) \right]$$ Literature:
  • boyle96: gives also elasticity formulas (seem wrong!)
  • cooper15
  • blacklow10
  • koch05
